story:
Hi Everyone,

Some of you may have read Chris's  blog about us serving as European Union election monitors in Sierra Leone last month and the extraordinary story of our teammate Issac, which you can read below.

Issac has gone from suffering unimaginably in the civil war to being half way through law school to serve his country as a human rights lawyer. Issac needs to raise $2,000 to fund this years fees by 17th December, and has already raised $300 from supporters in his local community.

We have committed to Issac that we will fundraise a scholarship of the remaining $1,700 from ourselves and our friends because we believe his example of perservance, positivity and public service in the face of extreme persecution is truly remarkable.

Issac has answered the John F Kennedy challenge of "Ask not what your country will do for you, ask what you can do for your country" under the most trying of circumstances and is quite simply the most inspirational person we have ever met.

We can think of no worthier receipient of educational scholarship.

So if you would like to give to something uniquely special this Christmas please join us in funding Issac's scholarship to enable him to realise his dream of serving the cause of justice and peace in Sierra Leone.


We would also be very grateful if you shared this on your facebook page.

Thank you,


Chris and Barbara

 

The tribal chief said “we pray for peaceful elections because we have seen it all.” They had. 11 years of war, 50,000 dead, amputations, rape, forced cannibalism. Waged by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) until 2001 on the people of Sierra Leone using child soldiers and conflict diamonds.

It was my first day in the field as a European Union election observer monitoring the 2012 Presidential elections. As the third elections since the end of the war, many commentators considered peaceful elections would mark Sierra Leone’s transition from a post conflict to more normal developing country, albeit the second poorest in the world. Elections have a raw emotional significance for Sierra Leonians: the RUF cut off people’s arms as punishment for voting. We met some of these amputees while investigating electoral access for vulnerable groups. There was something unbelievably shocking about it: That these people were missing arms not from injuries sustained in battle, but a deliberate act of torture from one human being to another. It is almost impossible to imagine the horror they went through, but I believe one should make the attempt so to understand that people face this injustice and it must be stopped.

Few people bought up the subject of the war but our assistant Issac did. He told us about running through a field with his father aged twelve. RUF bullets were thumping the soil around them. He shouted at his father to get down but Issac was injured, breaking his hip. Eventually they escaped into hiding but were unable to find enough food. His father starved to death.

Issac’s hip never healed correctly and he is unlikely to ever be able to afford the surgery to reset it. His mother died when he was much younger and as an only child it is easy to imagine him succumbing or becoming one more brutalised child soldier.

Instead, his father’s best friend took care of him and he went to secondary school. Issac’s father was a subsistence farmer and the family had no history of education but somehow Issac dreamt of becoming a human rights lawyer.  He passed the exam to get into university and started cold calling senior members of his community, telling them his story, his dream and asking for donations for his fees. A year later he had enough money for his first year.

Today Issac is a 24 year old top student with a linguistics degree and is half way through law school. He still depends on his community for support and is currently fundraising the $4,000 he needs for the final two years. He told me he wants to be a human rights lawyer to ensure no one suffers as he did and stand up against injustice in Sierra Leone. Perhaps he seeks release from his own anger in healing the hurt of others.

Thankfully the elections did pass peacefully and as international monitors our team was proud to play a role in enhancing Sierra Leonian’s confidence in the election process.

But if there is one reason why I’m optimistic about least developed countries escaping poverty it’s because I know their communities have extraordinary people like Issac who do not accept their situation, expand their sense of the possible, and lead.

 

North Bombali district EU election observer team: Chris, Abdoulaye, Barbara, Issac

story:
Benjamin Osorio’s Nordic Portfolio

 

Sports have always been a passion of mine. I have participated in many sports since I could walk, including cross-country running, soccer, swimming, basket-ball, badminton, volley-ball, track and field, and hockey. When I tried out Nordic skiing in grade 9, I thought that this was the hardest sport I had ever tried because it relied on the athlete being physically fit in not only a cardiovascular way, but in physical strength, endurance, balance as well as being mentally tough. I was instantly drawn to cross country skiing and joined the Arrowhead Nordic team the next year.

          By grade 11, I started really wondering what I was going to do with my future. It was then that I decided to become a professional athlete. The following year I got compartment syndrome in both legs, which left me unable to use them properly for skiing. I persevered none the less and came 16th at the Ontario High school championships, using mostly my upper body. This gave me the confidence I needed to believe that I had what it takes to compete on an international level and to one day represent Canada in the Olympics.

          I had a successful surgery in the spring of 2011, and since then I have been training to become the best I can be as a cross country skier. This year I have joined the Southern Ontario Training Centre (SOTC), with the strict guidance of a great coach. This is no longer High School racing and the cost is one that my family and I cannot afford. Travelling around the country, combined with equipment costs, racing fees, the SOTC program and tuition for university, all add up quickly, which is why I am in need of support.

I appreciate the time you have taken to consider my goal,

Benjamin Osorio

 

What is the Southern Ontario Training Centre?

SOTC is a high performance cross country ski training centre located near Barrie, ON, where, under the guidance of a full-time professional coach, athletes from across Ontario pursue excellence in competitive cross country skiing. Our mission is to help Ontario athletes achieve their dreams of representing Canada at the international level of the sport, while pursuing post-secondary education if they choose. SOTC athletes train together on a year round basis while representing their home clubs at provincial, national and continental competitions. SOTC is hosted by the Hardwood Hills Nordic Development Centre (HHNDC), utilizing the world class trails and other training amenities at Hardwood Ski and Bike and in the surrounding area.

Bio

Ben is a second year junior male from Huntsville, where he has represented Arrowhead Nordic for four years. This spring Ben finished high school where he skied on the Huntsville High School ski team and lead the senior boys to a second place finish at OFSAA for sprints and distance. This year Ben hopes to elevate his skiing and qualify for a national development center. Ben is also a part time student at Lakehead University where he is starting the concurrent education and outdoor recreation program this fall. Ben enjoys nearly all other sports and reading in his spare time.

Goal

 Qualify for the Canadian national team and compete in the 2018 Olympics.

Accomplishments: Made OFSAA Championships from grade 9-13, 5th at OFSAA 2012, 2nd place relay team finish OFSAA, made the Ontario Winter Games in last eligible year 2009, won Timmins Ontario Cup with 2 2nds and a 1st, Won Ontario Cup Series 2011-2012.

Expenses:

  • $4000 for the SOTC program
  • $1600 for race fees
  • $6000-$7000 travel expenses
  • $1500-$3000 Equipment expenses
  • $1200 in physiotherapy and consultation (psychology and nutrition)

 

 What I can do for you?

  • As an NCC level 2 certified coach in Nordic Skiing I can give lessons to you and/or your employees.
  • I can give a motivational speech to employees.
  • I retain a relationship with the Huntsville High School Nordic Ski Team, which has 60 members and the Arrowhead team, which has 10 members. What this means is that I can promote your service or product to the people of Huntsville. I compete on a national level, where I interact with many other racers, coaches and parents. I can therefore promote your service/product nationally.

 

You can reach me at benjaminosorio9@hotmail.com

story:
Last Man Stands World Champs, London 2013

The LMS World Champs are being held in London this year. The event is endorsed by the ECB and the opening games and final will be held at Lord's.

There will be 64 amateur cricket teams from around the world competing in the event, as well as the national chamions of Australia, South Africa, New Zealand & England.

http://lastmanstands.com/worldchamps/playcricke...

We want to take over a team comprised of young talented cricket from South Africa's township areas.

http://www.lastmanstands.com/alexandracricketcl...

What We Need & What You Get

We need $35 000.00 (around R280 000.00) to make this happen for 12 people from Alex to play in the LMS World Champs and stay in london for 10 days.

Flights are around R9 000.00 per person (R108 000.00 for 12 people)

Accomodation R5000.00 per person (R60 000.00 for 12 people)

London day travel card zones 1-4 £11/R156 per day x 10 dats (R18 720.00 for 12 people)

Food & drink R5000.00 per person for the tour (R60 000.00 for 12 people)

Documentary on the tour around R30 000.00

It's a once in a life time opportunity for these people, that would not ordinarily get a chance to travel to London, let a lone play at the home of cricket, Lord's.

 

The Impact

In 2012 we assisted the Massai Cricket Warriors travel to Cape Town to the LMS World Champs, and this ellevated their project massively. We now want to do the same for a new group of youngsters.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word and make this a reality. Speak to your boss, brother, neighbor etc. Use th Indiegogo share tools to get the word out there.

We are looking for 2 people (one from South Africa and one from UK) to assist us with documenting on video this tour from start to finish. If you have the skills or finance to help, please email bjorn@lastmanstands.net

story:
Who we are and what happened

Agora is a small non-profit group of architects based in Mae Sot. We focus on designing low cost buildings within the migrant community on the border between Thailand and Myanmar. 

In early 2012 we designed and constructed five student dormitories to house Burmese students at the Mae Tao Clinic training campus. Sadly on the 25th of February 2015 a fire from a neighbouring famers land spiralled out of control and destroyed all five buildings.

Fortunately of the 63 students living at the dormitories, no one was seriously hurt and only two boys suffered minor injuries, which were quickly treated at the Mae Tao Clinic. However the students now have nowhere to live and many of them lost all of their belongings.


Every baht counts

The dormitories were designed so that they could be easily dismantled and reconstructed at a very low cost, without wasting materials. In the coming months they were due to be relocated on a neighbouring site as part of the new Mae Tao Clinic project, which itself is funded by charitable donations. 

However following the fire none of the materials remain therefore the dormitories will need to be constructed completely from scratch and there just aren't the funds available to do this. 

Our initial goal is to raise enough money to rebuild at least one of the dormitory buildings. For the future Mae Tao Clinic is aiming to build a permanent dormitory building which we will support with the rest of the donations. If we aren't able to achieve this, any money we do raise could be used toward renting accommodation for the students or helping to replace belongings. 

Obviously it would be great to raise more than the target amount, as any additional funds could be used toward the construction and materials for the rest of the dormitories. But for now we are just taking it one step at a time. 


Please be patient with us

If and/or when we have the funds, we will start construction work as quickly as possible but as anyone who has been involved with a construction project knows, a lot preparation needs to be done before the actual building starts.
So if you generously contribute, although we won't be able to show you pictures of a finished buildings in the next few weeks we will make sure that we keep our facebook page updated with the progress of the project.

Other ways you can help

Even if you are not able to contribute yourself, please help us by spreading the word about this project.

We are extremely grateful for all the support that so many people have shown already. Thank you!

story:
Arts and Dementia Care

The Carolyn L. Farrell Foundation for Brain Health's mission is to empower those affected by dementia through art care and community outreach. The CLF Foundation was co-founded by Dr. Charles Farrell and Rev. Katie Norris. It bears the name of his wife and her mother, Carol, who just last month died from Lewy Body Dementia. The CLF Foundation runs a weekly art program for people with dementia in Westlake, Ohio which often includes music.

The Music and Memory program, which brings customized music to people with dementia living in care communities, has done extensive research on the benefits of music for people with dementia. The movie, "Alive Inside" is a dynamic documentary about the Music and Memory program. Unfortunately, not enough people know how music and the arts can increase the quality of life of people with dementia, and "Alive Inside" shows just how beneficial music is. Please watch the movie trailer to see how life changing music can be. 

In order to obtain public viewing rights of "Alive Inside" and bring it to communities in Ohio and beyond, we need to raise $600.   We already have plans for our first viewing of the movie with the West Shore Social Action Film Series to be held on April 11, 2015 at West Shore Unitarian Universalist Church in Rocky River, Ohio.

Funding for the public viewing rights of this movie will allow the CLF Foundation to bring this movie to many different audiences, providing:

  • Local experts who work with people with dementia through the arts as well as care partners of people with dementia who use the arts in their own home. 
  • Awareness about how art and music decrease agitation and other behavior challenges, and increase joy, in the life of a person with dementia. 
  • Help to people living at home with dementia and their care partners to obtain free education and resources about dementia care.
Please help us raise the funds to bring this important movie to as many communities as possible!
Thank you for helping to increase education around dementia and the arts.

story:
This past November, five remarkable young women visited Smith College and fell in love with the beautiful campus and the wealth of opportunities available to students. One student, a computer enthusiast and vegetarian, saw herself joining both the engineering program and the animal rights club. Another has long envisioned herself as a neuroscientist with a specialty in early cognitive development, and was excited by Smith's flourishing science programs. Another student, an accomplished public speaker at only age twenty, was inspired by Smithies' passion for social issues.

Each of these students has applied to Smith, and all are competitive applicants. However, one major hurdle to attending stands in their way: they are all undocumented. Banned from the top five public universities in their anti-immigrant home state of Georgia, Smith seems to them a breath of fresh air. However, their chances of admission to Smith are much lower than for documented American students with otherwise similar applications. When applying to Smith, undocumented students are currently considered part of the international applicant pool, which is twice as competitive as the domestic pool. This process is explicitly need-conscious, which means that an applicant’s ability to pay plays a role in the admission decision. Undocumented applicants, many of whom have grown up in under-resourced U.S. communities, must compete with wealthy international students who have often had access to elite schools and extensive resume building opportunities. Additionally, while domestic students are not required to submit SAT/ACT scores (the results of which have been shown to correlate with income), international students are not exempt, resulting in another hurdle for prospective students who lack legal status. Smith's domestic admission rate is about 40%, but as international students with high financial need, undocumented applicants face an admit rate of approximately 10%. At the same time, undocumented students are not eligible for federal grants or student loans. In other words, undocumented students with few financial resources face patently unfair barriers to attending Smith.

Top schools like Harvard, Dartmouth, Stanford, Duke, Notre Dame, Oberlin, and the University of Chicago now recognize that undocumented access to college is a pressing ethical and civil rights issue, and have changed their policies and funding priorities. Many of these institutions explicitly welcome applications from undocumented students and are committed to using institutional funds to meet the financial need of those admitted. Other schools, like Harvard, have pledged not to use citizenship status as a factor in admissions decisions. While regressive legislation in states like Georgia and Arizona tell undocumented youth that they are only fit for low-wage jobs, these leading schools send the message that these young people deserve access to institutions of higher learning. As alumnae, we believe it's time for Smith to take the lead, too, by welcoming talented young undocumented women onto campus!

The organizers of this campaign invite fellow alumnae, as well as current students, faculty, staff, and any others who value equity for immigrants and their children, to pledge their support for this cause by joining us in funding a scholarship to help an undocumented young woman attend Smith. Our current goal is $10,000 (the extra $400 is to cover Indiegogo's 4% fee.)  While we know this is a long way from what it would cost to fund a Smith education for even one year, we want to show the administration that this is an issue alumnae will stand behind. Our hope is that it will be enough to convince the College to admit - and fund - a qualified undocumented student who otherwise would not be granted admission.

Hampshire College endowed a scholarship for undocumented students two years ago, thanks to alumni donations. Just this fall, Oberlin’s community raised over $10,000 for an undocumented student scholarship. Let’s join them and show Smith administrators and the Board of Trustees that this matters to us. Undocumented students belong at Smith, too!


Signed:

Alexis Estrella ‘10

Ali Harris ‘08

Alli Langley ‘13

Amanda Lee Keammerer '09

Candace Gibson ‘07

Catherine Moriarty AC ‘09

Claire Bolton ‘08

Denisse Martinez ‘13

Dior Vargas ‘09

Ellen Weiss Wiewel ‘01

Ginetta E.B. Candelario '90

Huelo Dunn-Estébanez ‘07

Jasmina Chuck ‘11

Jennifer Larese ‘10

Jessica Gutierrez '12

Marilyn Flores ‘09

Melissa Redwood ‘10

Michelle Restrepo ‘10

Sara Carlson ‘09

Sarah Brickey-Nguyen '09

& The current members of Smith's Organizing for Undocumented Students’ Rights group (OUSR)

vegetarian, saw herself joining both the engineering program and the animal
rights club. Another has long envisioned herself as a neuroscientist with a
specialty in early cognitive development, and was excited by Smith's
flourishing science programs. Another student, an accomplished public speaker
at only age twenty, was inspired by Smithies' passion for social issues.
Each of these students has applied to Smith, and all are
competitive applicants. However, one major hurdle to attending stands in their
way: they are all undocumented. Banned from the top five public universities in
their anti-immigrant home state of Georgia, Smith seems to them a breath of
fresh air. However, their chances of admission to Smith are much lower than for
documented American students with otherwise similar applications. When applying
to Smith, undocumented students are currently considered part of the
international applicant pool, which is twice as competitive as the domestic
pool. This process is explicitly need-conscious, which means that an
applicant’s ability to pay plays a role in the admission decision. Undocumented
applicants, many of whom have grown up in under-resourced U.S. communities,
must compete with wealthy international students who have often had access to
elite schools and extensive resume building opportunities. Additionally, while
domestic students are not required to submit SAT/ACT scores (the results of
which have been shown to correlate with income), international students are not
exempt, resulting in another hurdle for prospective students who lack legal
status. Smith's domestic admission rate is about 40%, but as international
students with high financial need, undocumented applicants face an admit rate
of approximately 10%. At the same time, undocumented students are not eligible for
federal grants or student loans. In other words, undocumented students with few financial
resources face patently unfair barriers to attending Smith.
Top schools like Harvard, Dartmouth, Stanford, Duke, Notre
Dame, Oberlin, and the University of Chicago now recognize that undocumented
access to college is a pressing ethical and civil rights issue, and have
changed their policies and funding priorities. Many of these institutions
explicitly welcome applications from undocumented students and are committed to
using institutional funds to meet the financial need of those admitted. Other
schools, like Harvard, have pledged not to use citizenship status as a factor
in admissions decisions. While regressive legislation in states like Georgia
and Arizona tell undocumented youth that they are only fit for low-wage jobs,
these leading schools send the message that these young people deserve access
to institutions of higher learning. As alumnae, we believe it's time for Smith
to take the lead, too, by welcoming talented young undocumented women onto
campus!
The organizers of this campaign invite fellow alumnae, as
well as current students, faculty, staff, and any others who value equity for
immigrants and their children, to pledge their support for this cause by
joining us in funding a scholarship to help an undocumented young woman attend
Smith. Our current goal is $10,000 (the extra $400 is to cover Indiegogo's 4% fee.)  While we know this is a long way from what
it would cost to fund a Smith education for even one year, we want to show the
administration that this is an issue alumnae will stand behind. Our hope is
that it will be enough to convince the College to admit - and fund - a
qualified undocumented student who otherwise would not be granted admission.
Hampshire College endowed a scholarship for undocumented
students two years ago, thanks to alumni donations. Just this fall, Oberlin’s
community raised over $10,000 for an undocumented student scholarship. Let’s
join them and show Smith administrators and the Board of Trustees that this
matters to us. Undocumented students belong at Smith, too!
Signed:
Alexis Estrella ‘10
Ali Harris ‘08
Alli Langley ‘13
Amanda Lee Keammerer '09
Candace Gibson ‘07
Catherine Moriarty AC ‘09
Claire Bolton ‘08
Denisse Martinez ‘13
Dior Vargas ‘09
Ellen Weiss Wiewel ‘01Ginetta E.B. Candelario '90
Huelo Dunn-Estébanez ‘07
Jasmina Chuck ‘11
Jennifer Larese ‘10Jessica Gutierrez '12
Marilyn Flores ‘09
Melissa Redwood ‘10
Michelle Restrepo ‘10
Sara Carlson ‘09
Sarah Brickey-Nguyen '09
& The current members of Smith's Organizing for Undocumented
Students’ Rights group (OUSR)

story:
ClayToGo Van for Northern Clay Center

We are Northern Clay Center, a fabulous not-for-profit ceramic art center in south Minneapolis, Minnesota. Since 1999, our original ClayMobile has reached offsite audiences across the state, transported 100,000+ clay art pieces to and from our outreach partners, and it has toured dozens of NCC exhibitions across the state and the country. The vehicle is nearing retirement age and a new, more environmentally friendly cargo van will allow us to increase offsite programming and satellite exhibitions.

Contribute to our fund today to enable us continue to bring ceramic art education to thousands of people across Minnesota via a reliable, purpose-fit, and efficient ClayToGo Van!

About Northern Clay Center and ClayToGo

Northern Clay Center is entering our 26th year of operations, and, since our start, we’ve become an established part of the local arts community and we have garnered national recognition for the quality and scope of our programs. The Clay Center is the only comprehensive ceramic arts organization in the region and is one of the largest, if not the largest, such organization in the country. We have become a model for other medium-based education and artist service organizations.

NCC’s ClayToGo programs (for schools and community groups) are produced in partnership with Twin Cities schools and other arts organizations. ART@HAND is a subsidiary program of ClayToGo, which serves adults 55+ in a variety of settings (at NCC, in nursing homes and care centers, at independent living centers, etc.) We provide short visits and extended artist residencies through these programs using our original ClayMobile; we host tours and artist demonstrations for groups (corporate employees, students, civic groups, birthday parties, etc.); and we lead hands-on, public programs during neighborhood festivals and other arts conferences.

Since 1999, the original ClayMobile—a retrofitted cube truck originally purchased and outfitted to move the heavy and cumbersome equipment required to work with clay—has reached offsite audiences across the state, and transported over 100,000 clay art pieces to and from our outreach partners. The original ClayMobile has enabled us to serve over 95,500 individuals through offsite programming, through over 2,800 unique collaborations via ClayToGo and ART@HAND.

We’ve toured the original ClayMobile throughout the state of Minnesota for traveling exhibitions and offsite ceramic sales, some of which are in collaboration with other art centers or museums. It’s taken us to Milwaukee, WI; Providence, RI; and, this past spring, Kansas City, MO; for offsite gallery sales at the annual National Council on Education for the Ceramic Arts (NCECA) conference—enabling us to show over 3,000 pots to over 11,000 people in just three short years.

We’ve put a lot of miles on the original ClayMobile, and as it grows older, the cost of repairs and general operations also grows. Despite our diligent maintenance, the original ClayMobile is growing increasingly unreliable, which limits our outreach initiatives. A new, more environmentally friendly cargo van will allow us to increase offsite programming and satellite exhibitions and continue to reach audiences who are unable to get to our Minneapolis location.

What We Need and What You Get

We need a new purpose-fit van to ensure that we can continue to bring ceramic art to thousands of people across Minnesota.

As of the start of this campaign, the new ClayToGo Van has been ordered! Our friends at Boyer Truck in Minneapolis have secured a Ford Transit Cargo Van for NCC’s new, soon to be ClayToGo Van, and with any luck, we’ll have it outfitted and covered in lively drawings donated by local ceramic artist Mike Norman in early Fall 2016!

This vehicle is essential to the continued success of NCC’s outreach and exhibitions programs. Our current truck is on its last legs and without a replacement, we will not be able to expand our outreach programming and continue our touring exhibitions. The new ClayToGo Van will ensure that we are able to continue to deliver and expand our outreach and exhibition programming well into the future.

We need to raise $15,000 to cover customization of the vehicle, which includes:

  • extended roof and length options on the van to maximize carrying capacity
  • the requisite interior modifications such as racks, strapping system, the partition to protect our driver
  • a light-weight, aluminum platform liftgate that will enable the smooth transition of fragile projects and other artwork onto and off the van
  • insurance/tabs/licensing for the first two years of operation
  • wrapping the exterior of the van with lively graphics

If we exceed our goal of $15,000, additional funds will help to underwrite the cost of the van itself.

We’ve secured over $15,000 to date, from two generous donors, but we still have a ways to go! Help us get there, fast! Every donation counts and brings us closer to expanding our ClayToGo programs to more schools, care centers, nursing homes, community centers, art fairs, and other venues. Give today and all of your donation dollars will go directly towards the startup costs of this new ClayToGo Van!

  • At the $5 level, you’ll receive our heartfelt thanks through a 10-second iPhone video from NCC's outreach manager, and we’ll be sure to send some major warm fuzzies your way!
  • At the $25 level, you’ll receive an NCC button and ClayToGo temporary tattoo.
  • At the $50 donor level, you’ll receive a limited edition ClayToGo t-shirt.
  • At the $100 donor level, you’ll receive a commemorative ClayToGo-inspired mug made by one of our teaching artists.
  • At the $250 level, you’ll receive a limited edition, commemorative print by artist Mike Norman.
  • At the $500 level, we’ll send a commemorative cup your way, as well as print your name on the back door of the new ClayToGo Van. And we’ll treat you and up to 10 friends to a tour and artist demonstration at Northern Clay Center.
  • At the $1000 and beyond level, we’ll throw in all of the above perks AND invite you to enjoy a free ride-along in the new ClayToGo Van, and to brunch with NCC’s fabulously talented outreach teaching artists!

*All of our donors will receive a shout out on social media and recognition on our website and in our annual report.

Regardless of your giving level, please share this worthy cause with all of your friends who place value on arts, ceramics, and education! Give today and become part of the next exciting chapter of our outreach programming!

TAX DEDUCTIBLE DONATION

Your contribution to the ClayToGo Van is tax-deductible! Northern Clay Center is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. Contributions to NCC are tax-deductible, less the value of any goods or services received, as allowed by law. The value of goods and services being offered is noted under each donation level. If you would like to deduct the entire donation, you have the option to simply decline the reward at check out.

story:
Handheld Stories – India 

Handheld Stories is a volunteer-based, educational and media-arts collaborative that provides media creation tools and training for atâ€risk youth worldwide. Handheld places an emphasis on working with underrepresented, marginalized communities where planning a secure and stable future is compromised by political, social or economic circumstances.

Handheld Stories provides the equipment, the volunteers, and the curriculum for a wholesale video training experience. At the culmination of these workshops, Handheld trainees have acquired the skills necessary for semi-professional video production and broadcast.

Dharavi Slum, located in the heart of Mumbai, is home to nearly 1 million people living in an area roughly 1 square mile in size. That’s about 18,000 people per acre, and many exist with no running water, electricity health care or educational opportunities. By contributing to this project you are accomplishing 2 important goals, you will be providing a unique educational opportunity out of the reach of many of these children as well as bringing to light the situation in Dharavi as told by the kids who live there.

This is an awesome opportunity for these kids. A fundamental aspect of any Handheld Workshop is the legacy project – meaning the equipment, and the skills to use and transfer those skills, remain with the students.

Where the money goes.

  • Cameras and Laptops that stay with the children.
  • Travel and accomodation expenses for our all-volunteer staff.
Many Ways to Contribute

Please tell your friends, colleagues or anyone you think might be interested in funding this campaign.  Even if you can't contribute you can still help us spread the word! Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr and anywhere you hang out online. Every bit makes a difference!

story:
After watching the video above, for more details and a different perspective on helping impoverished communities to be able to take care of themselves and their orphans, watch this 3 minute video

   http://www.screencast.com/t/Fi3bKmDe6  

 Do you see now, after watching it, how it is possible to care for communities and orphans without government money or ongoing donations? 

The Sustainable Communities of Families Adopting Children are designed to do just that. Helping people to help themselves.

This project started after adopting two older children (10 and 12) from a traditional orphanage in Mexico, then over the next five years, taking them to visit the friends they had grown up with (who were still without families), I saw, with my own eyes, an amazing  development gap begin to form.

I saw the difference adoption, parents and a home can make in the lives of orphans.

That development gap and knowing the terrible conditions in which many orphans live, caused me to ask,

"How can we get more orphans adopted into real families?"

A new nonprofit was formed and since then, over 600 volunteers from 18 different countries have contributed ideas for the design of Sustainable Adoption Communities!

Then, the:

University of Colorado College of Architecture and Planning put it all into a Master Plan for us

and other design support has come from 

CU Leeds School of Management 

Colorado School of Mines 

Metro State College of Denver 

Adams State University 

and many more organizations and individuals helping to create this opportunity for the children.

We have the design, now we need the land on which to build it.

As you saw in the video, this project will create a self-sustaining community of families adopting children.  It will not need any government money or ongoing donations!  The "economic engine" businesses in the community will make this possible. All the profits from the businesses stay in the project mission to keep the community operating.  Some of the funds will also be used to help start more sustainable communities around the world. The businesses create over 100 jobs, skills training for adolescents, food and the profits. This is not a charity project. The parents will earn their wages to rent a home, buy the food and things needed for their families. As a benefit of working for the businesses, costs of adoptions will be paid by the businesses.

Imagine if we could have done this for the children you saw in the video.  

How many of these self-sustaining communities can we use around our world?

We need your help now,

   to be able to get the land. We are anticipating that it will take about $200,000 in total to get the land we need for the project. We are asking our Indiegogo supporters to help with $5,000 of that as the goal. 

We are also discussing this project with sponsors and foundations in both the USA and Mexico for the rest of the funds needed for the land and the construction.  Once the businesses are built, it is self-sustaining economically and will finish building itself out from then on.

100% of the funds received go to implementation of this project. Our staff and board of directors are passionate and dedicated volunteers who are here to help the children and who take no money for doing it.

 Think about the impact of this "solution" to helping communities and orphans.

You probably know that children on the street or in traditional orphanages have poor health, little education, few if any job skills, poor social skills, have no idea what a family is or does, and are not prepared for their, or their country's future. They become liabilities for their society.

 This project, will get orphans into financially stable families and communities, where they will receive the love, care, education and preparation to be productive citizens, assets for their society.

Pass it on.

Please tell others about this amazing new way to help communities, orphans and their adopting parents. Your Facebook friends, email list, colleagues at work or school, twitter, and more, please spread the work. You can start by using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Our project

The project on which the interns will be working on is called Rbtrium and our startup is called Collective Decision Making Enterprises (CDE). 

Rbtrium is a Collective Decision Making platform and a new paradigm for daily managerial decisions within organizations. Through us our future clients will gain access to the latest tools & techniques in management, resource allocation, overview & tracking of collective decision-making results.

 

We will be dealing directly with our clients, to help them understand and overcome the obstacles responsible for inefficiencies and delays in their projects and daily operations. We optimize our clients’ decision making workflow. Our potential clients are government branches, local municipal communities and large and medium size corporations. 

http://www.rbtrium.com

 

Why do we combine our project with career building for students?

Members of our team have all benefitted from real life internships during our own academic career. It seems only natural to pass on such a unique experience to others. Not only are we starting a new company, but we are sharing that experience and hopefully giving our future interns the desire to explore opportunities within entrepreneurship.

 

The internship program

We would like to share our first entrepreneurial steps with ambitious and international students in the field of Data Analysis, Marketing and Finance,

We would like to introduce them to the startup scene in Barcelona, invite them to entrepreneurship events through our network, provide them with a working space together with other like-minded individuals and share our experience from previous projects. The interns will be guided by the CTO and CFO of the project. They will have 2 career coaching sessions with our CEO who is a serial entrepreneur with several startups under his belt.

  • Insight into the entrepreneurial community in Barcelona

  • Internship in an early stage tech startup

  • International work experience for students

 

The students will experience both the work discipline required for succeeding in a startup and also the positive input working with seasoned professionals will bring to their understanding of the modern day work environment. Their work will be task driven and measured through evaluation processes. We will also give them access to our very extensive network.

 

How exactly will the funding be used?

  • Coworking space spots

  • Entry fees to startup events

  • Team building activities

  • Spanish language lessons

  • And some bonus and subsidy to pay for their relocation and stay in Barcelona during the internship

 

To ensure appropriate infrastructure for hosting the interns, we will need some funding. This will include: some modest remuneration to interns to cover basic cost of living, costs related to their working environment in a co-working space, entry fees to various startup events, team building activities, partial tuition fee for their Spanish language lessons with a professional language school we collaborate with and interesting hiking trips to discover the region and its history. We would like our interns to have the best experience possible both professionally and personally by coming to Barcelona.

 

Timeline

  • August: Interviews with candidates

  • September: Welcome to interns

  • September - December: Internship

  • December: Goodbye

 

Risks and challenges

It is important to us that the hosted students possess a high degree of hunger and curiosity for knowledge and the tasks at hand. They will be concentrating on our project during the internship and we will be concentrating on their development, so they benefit from the full potential of their talent for future progress. We are fully aware that their internship experience can be their first international living experience. It can change their lives and we will do our best to ensure that they have all the support they need. However, we cannot do this without your help as it will require resources that we as a first stage startup do not possess.

We want to promote the entrepreneurship spirit and international experience for student interns. We want to help young people to further develop their careers, so please donate generously.

It seems only natural to pass on such a unique experience to others. Not only are we starting a new company, but we are sharing that experience and hopefully giving our future interns the desire to explore opportunities within entrepreneurship. The internship programWe would like to share our first entrepreneurial steps with ambitious and international students in the field of Data Analysis, Marketing and Finance,We would like to introduce them to the startup scene in Barcelona, invite them to entrepreneurship events through our network, provide them with a working space together with other like-minded individuals and share our experience from previous projects. The interns will be guided by the CTO and CFO of the project. They will have 2 career coaching sessions with our CEO who is a serial entrepreneur with several startups under his belt.
Insight into the entrepreneurial community in Barcelona
Internship in an early stage tech startup
International work experience for students
 The students will experience both the work discipline required for succeeding in a startup and also the positive input working with seasoned professionals will bring to their understanding of the modern day work environment. Their work will be task driven and measured through evaluation processes. We will also give them access to our very extensive network. How exactly will the funding be used?
Coworking space spots
Entry fees to startup events
Team building activities
Spanish language lessons
And some bonus and subsidy to pay for their relocation and stay in Barcelona during the internship
 To ensure appropriate infrastructure for hosting the interns, we will need some funding. This will include: some modest remuneration to interns to cover basic cost of living, costs related to their working environment in a co-working space, entry fees to various startup events, team building activities, partial tuition fee for their Spanish language lessons with a professional language school we collaborate with and interesting hiking trips to discover the region and its history. We would like our interns to have the best experience possible both professionally and personally by coming to Barcelona. Timeline
August: Interviews with candidates
September: Welcome to interns
September - December: Internship
December: Goodbye
 Risks and challengesIt is important to us that the hosted students possess a high degree of hunger and curiosity for knowledge and the tasks at hand. They will be concentrating on our project during the internship and we will be concentrating on their development, so they benefit from the full potential of their talent for future progress. We are fully aware that their internship experience can be their first international living experience. It can change their lives and we will do our best to ensure that they have all the support they need. However, we cannot do this without your help as it will require resources that we as a first stage startup do not possess.We want to promote the entrepreneurship spirit and international experience for student interns. We want to help young people to further develop their careers, so please donate generously.

story:
I'm a 24-year-old Oregonian living in California and passionate about contributing to organizations working to elevate the world. 

Through my studies in government and journalism, I learned what an important factor a sustainable education system is in developing countries as opposed to simply dropping off supplies and leaving. Through my work as a manager, I've learned that it's through leadership training that sustainability in an organization can happen -- whether it be a country, a company or a school. 

For these reasons I support the work that imagine1day is doing in Ethiopian communities. 

Since 2007, they have funded 123 primary schools, trained 1,700 teachers and built 26 schools from the ground up. Their goal is for all Ethiopians to have access to quality education funded free of foreign aid by the year 2030. 

I'm asking for $1000 as a deposit on my trip to Ethiopia with imagine1day, which I will go on after raising $7000 for the organization. Every penny of that $7000 will go towards building a school in the country. 

Please help me support this awesome non-profit and continue the work they've done!

To find out more about imagine1day, visit their website at imagine1day.org. 

Big gratitude coming your way! -- McKenna

story:
The Model UN club at Beacon High School has an ambitious and exciting new goal this year -- to go to a conference out of state for the first time in our history!  It’s something this years’ leadership and club feels very passionate about and are eager to make it happen!  


The Model UN (MUN) club at The Beacon School has provided each of its members with the opportunity to strengthen their public speaking and debating skills and to increase their awareness of current political, social, and economic issues.  I have devoted the past four years of my life to this club because of the skills I’ve gained from negotiating with other young adults from around the world and because of the strong community of passionate young delegates I have found at Beacon.  I know that my sentiments are felt throughout the entire club, so we thought it was time we share our passion and knowledge at a new, exciting, and completive conference in Washington DC. 

This conference, located at George Washington University is one of the best in the country. Over the course of the four debating days, held between March 19-22nd, delegates will attempt to create solutions to some of the world's most pressing topics, such as non-proliferation of nuclear and biological weapons, the treatment of women in conflict zones and creating stability for refugees across the globe. Some delegates will also be in historical committees, which look at past situations and search for better resolutions than those made at the time of their occurance. In all, thousands of students will be debating dozens of fascinating topics. 


Any donation would be greatly appreciated!  While many schools have each member pay for their individual conference fees, we would rather everyone have an equal opportunity to go, no matter what their economic situation is.  Your kind donations will go towards delegate, school, and chaperon fees, as well as towards transportation and hotel costs.  Please be a part of making our goal of going out of state a reality!  


Thank you,

Isabella Smith, Chief Treasurer

story:
This campaign is to raise funds to build families and communities. We do this by getting foster children out of foster care and into a real, forever home with caring family members instead of being forced out into the streets at 18 years old, alone and with no family support. We build communities because we save foster care agencies millions of dollars that can now be redirected to community infrastructure improvements such as streetlights, sidewalks and fire stations.


Update

We have passed our goal of $3,000. Now we're looking to help build twice as many families and give more foster children a brighter future. Help us reach our new goal of $6,000.

We also have two very unique perks by Robert Aragon as well as an original commissioned sketch by Victor Olazaba of Spider-Man.


A Foster Child's Story

Let me share one of our cases. Veronica is 15 years old. She’s your typical teenager. She was living with her father and thinking about her senior year, dating and going out with her friends. Boom! Her whole world just changed because her dad was sent to prison for 10 years. Veronica was moved out of her house and placed into foster care. She was moved to a new school and away from her friends. At 15 years old, there is almost no chance that Veronica will be adopted. On her 18th birthday, Veronica will be essentially put out on the street, alone and with no support and no family.

Once on the street, she had a 90% chance of becoming homeless, turning to drugs or prostitution, getting raped, becoming pregnant or ending up in prison all before her 20th birthday unless something happened to change her future right away!

Foster children are resilient, smart and adaptable. They just want a chance to have the same life as other kids. There are 84,000 more foster youths just like Veronica who need someone to help give them that chance at a better future.


A Proven Solution

The great news is that there is a solution and it’s been around for more than 20 years. It’s called Find Families In Mexico.  Foster care agencies across the U.S. bring us their foster children cases when case workers have been unable to locate relatives in the U.S. but there might be family members living in Mexico.

We have a 95% success rate in locating relatives. Our success almost always results in other relatives being located in the U.S. so that ultimately foster children are placed with family members or adoptive parents.

Average cost per foster child case is $500. The service we provide to foster care agencies is pro bono (free). The number of cases we can take on is limited by the donations we receive. The activity of finding families in Mexico includes:

  • Documentation and government report fees 
  • Research materials and database costs
  • International calls
  • Bilingual support staff, translators
  • On the ground investigators in Mexico
There are hard expenses that must be covered on a per-case basis to support our work including:
  • Overhead and office supplies, printing expenses
  • Accounting, government filings
  • Fundraising costs
  • Indiegogo campaign fee.

Why We Need Your Help!

This campaign will provide the funding so our organization can take on six to eight new foster children cases meaning that at least eight foster youths just like Veronica won’t have to spend years in the foster care system. Instead these kids will be living in a permanent home with loving, caring relatives or adoptive parents. They’ll do better in school, make friends, graduate and go on to college. And when they graduate, these former foster kids will be in the 10% who will be able to get a job and hold onto it and have the confidence and support to go out on their own and succeed.


We reached our $3,000 milestone!

Thank you to everyone, especially Tom Antion and all of the people who took advantage of his very generous offer. In case you didn't get the news, Tom is giving triple value for his perk (See $500 - Consultation with Tom Antion), Now when you get the perk, you will receive three 30 minute consults with Tom. If you want to position you and your business for success in 2015, your time with Tom will be invaluable.


Our Stretch Goal $6,000

So now that we have passed $3,000, it's time to look to our stretch goal of $6,000. This will allow our organization can take on 12-15 new foster children cases.


Here Is How the Money Will Be Spent

$6,000 will allow our organization to take on 12-15 new foster children cases.

We average 1.5 foster children per case. Some cases involve one child while others include several siblings. We project being able to help 18-23 foster children.

This $6,000 will help reduce foster care spending by about $4,370,000 (based on 23 foster children with an average support cost of $190,000 per child).

Or all of us including businesses can pay up to $300,000 per foster child forced out of the foster care system to fend for themselves on the street. Our goal of $6,000 will give 23 foster children a much brighter future and save taxpayers roughly $6.9 million.

How Our Work Builds Communities

The $6.9 million we can save in taxpayer dollars can be used to improve or expand community services such as streetlights, sidewalks and fire stations. For instance, $6.9 million is the amount that Jersey City needed to retain or hire 49 firefighters.  

The majority of the funds goes directly into the work of researching and locating a foster child's family members living in Mexico. It can be very challenging to locate people there because Mexico lacks national databases. Don't think that a Google search will work.


Our founder, Richard Villasana, is one of the leading international experts on Mexico genealogy. People from around the world contact him to help them find their relatives and ancestors after they've tried everything including Google, Facebook and Twitter. He has reunited families from more than 10 countries, such as Australia, Germany and Ireland with their Mexican relatives.

In most every case we handle, the family members in Mexico will have contact information on other relatives living in the U.S. resulting in foster children being placed with them.

Your contribution will help make a positive, lasting change for every foster child we serve.



Veronica's New Future

Our organization received Veronica’s case and in just a few weeks, we located her birth mother. That was pretty exciting, but it gets better because Veronica’s mother told social services where to find two of the girl’s aunts living in New York. It happens a lot that children with relatives in Mexico also have relatives in the U.S. So where did Veronica go? That’s right. She moved out of foster care to live with her aunts in New York. That’s what we call "making a lasting change in a foster child’s life."

Now Here’s How You Can Help

SPECIAL PERK

We have a late entry for our perks. We have an original sketch from Victor Olazaba, one of the comic book industry’s premier inkers. His credits include Spawn, Spider-Man, and work over nearly every major Marvel character.

If you know a superhero fan or happen to be one yourself, then this sketch is for you. Check out the perk "Original Spider-Man Sketch."

We also have perks from Robert Aragon, one of the leading fine art portrait artists in the world. Check out his two unique perks, "A Tiny Teddy Named Cuds" and "Frankenstein Lives." You can also read more about Robert Aragon in the Dec. 19 update.


Make a contribution and get a perk. There is something for everyone from top business experts. Whether you work at a company, have your own business or want to start your own company, there is some program or service that will help you move toward your goals. If you want expert advice on improving your sales, getting new clients, keeping clients and more, then you will find that advice here.



Help by Spreading the Word

Not ready to get a perk? You can still support a foster child by getting the word out about this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and other sites. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Post on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram and others about this campaign.
  • Visit our YouTube channel, comment and share on the videos from our contributors.
  • If you work for a company, ask them to get a perk and use it for training. 
  • If you need a lead generation contact service such as Aweber, by clicking the link our organization will receive a periodic payment.
  • If you need a shopping cart, the leading cart for small businesses is KickStartCart. When you click the link and sign up, our organization will receive a periodic payment.

story:
Blues Rules selon Les Inrockuptibles :

Le Blues Rules est une vraie réussite. Une alternative aux gros festivals établis (Paléo ou Montreux), avec une programmation à la fois éclectique et pointue (beaucoup d'américains que l'on voit rarement en Europe), sur un site bucolique (le parc du château) à la taille humaine.

2017 : 8ème édition

Grace à votre soutien le jour J, nous tenons bon et sommes fiers de vous accueillir (vous et les musiciens) pour une nouvelle édition du BRCF, avec :

  •  Un hommage à Junior Kimbrough
  •  14 groupes sur 2 soirées exceptionnelles
  •  Un moment unique à vivre entre amis et/ou en famille

► Prenez vos billets en avance
► Réservez un PASS VIP !
► Offrez un T-shirt à vos amis
► PASS St Valentin *exclusif*

Rester "petit" est un challenge et surtout une envie

A l'heure de la démesure, de la course au succès garanti, du risque zéro, nous avons décidé de rester des artisans de l'open-air, et plutôt que de céder aux mélopées des sirènes tête d'affiche bankable nous décidons que nous ne grandirons pas !

Rester un festival dans une pâture au pied d'un château d'un village du canton de Vaud est un challenge de tous les jours, et ce n'est possible que grace au soutien de nos fidèles festivaliers (et de nos bénévoles), et ne nous leurrons pas, nous avons besoin de vous !

Notre petite taille ne permet donc pas d'inviter les pointures radio-diffusées et cela nous conforte dans l'envie de partager avec vous ce qu'est le Real Deal, le Blues vrai, celui qui servait au divertissement, le soir dans un Juke Joint non-loin du Crossroad où Robert Johnson vendit son âme au diable, après une dure journée de labeur...
C'est donc là où le Blues Rules Crissier Festival propose l'alternative aux grosses machines !
Une scène unique où se succèdent durant 2 soirs des artistes au talent incontestable...
Quelle fierté d'être le festival qui réalisa 12 premières européennes pour des artistes américains talentueux (Leo Bud Welsh (82 ans), Molly Gene, ...), la dernière tournée de Robert Belfour (2013), une scène pour 25 groupes suisses !!! et ce n'est pas fini (grace à vous)...

    Pourquoi une levée de fond ?

    Avoir de la trésorerie permet d'avoir de l'argent avant le jour J, et donc de :

    • Créer et imprimer des affiches, flyers, sous-bock, stickers et tous moyens de communication pour que ce soit une réussite !
    • Payer les billets d'avion des artistes américains qui viennent pour la première fois en Europe (et que chez nous).
    • 2000- c'est 20% de nos besoin en mars, mais nous préférons les bonnes surprises ☺

    Risques et défis

    Nous savons qu'il est de plus en plus difficile de savoir de quoi demain sera fait, de prévoir un weekend aussi longtemps à l'avance, mais certains d'entre-vous ne manquerez pour rien au monde cette nouvelle édition, alors allez-y, bloquez votre agenda et profitez de ces petits prix.

    •  Avec plus de 900 visiteurs par jour (pour une capacité maximale de 1000), assurez-vous d'en être.
    • Soyez ainsi les sponsors d'artistes qui ne sont pas dans le circuit habituel.

    D'autres façons d'aider :

    Certains d'entres vous ne peuvent pas contribuer (pour l'instant) mais cela ne veut pas dire que vous ne pouvez pas aider :

    • Parlez-en autour de vous.
    • Partagez cette page Indiegogo
    • Partagez l'événement de facebook : https://www.facebook.com/events/1215968271794590/
    • Venez directement les 19 et 20 mai à Crissier.

    Programmation 2017 :

    Voici les 14 groupes qui animeront le festival :

    • Robert Kimbrough Sr. (USA) - Fils de Junior Kimbrough
    • The Hillbilly Moon Explosion (CH)
    • Reverend Peyton's Big Damn Band (USA)
    • Duck Duck Grey Duck (CH)
    • Cameron Kimbrough (USA) - petit-fils de Junior Kimbrough
    • Son of Dave (USA)
    • Ms Nickki & the Memphis Soul Connection (USA)
    • One Rusty Band n'Tap (CH)
    • Mark Muleman Massey (USA)
    • Ronan One Man Band (F)
    • Crushed Out (USA)
    • Sergi Estella (E)
    • The Blues Spirit Band (CH)
    • The Marshals (F)
      ​+ DJ Phil (CH)

    (programmation arrêtée au 12/01/2017, sous réserve d'annulation ou de modification)

    And let's boogie all night long!

    Masterclass avec le Rev' Peyton :

    Apprenez le fingerpicking et le slide avec un des virtuoses du genre :

Rester un festival dans une pâture au pied d'un château d'un village du canton de Vaud est un challenge de tous les jours, et ce n'est possible que grace au soutien de nos fidèles festivaliers (et de nos bénévoles), et ne nous leurrons pas, nous avons besoin de vous !
Notre petite taille ne permet donc pas d'inviter les pointures radio-diffusées et cela nous conforte dans l'envie de partager avec vous ce qu'est le Real Deal, le Blues vrai, celui qui servait au divertissement, le soir dans un Juke Joint non-loin du Crossroad où Robert Johnson vendit son âme au diable, après une dure journée de labeur...C'est donc là où le Blues Rules Crissier Festival propose l'alternative aux grosses machines !Une scène unique où se succèdent durant 2 soirs des artistes au talent incontestable...Quelle fierté d'être le festival qui réalisa 12 premières européennes pour des artistes américains talentueux (Leo Bud Welsh (82 ans), Molly Gene, ...), la dernière tournée de Robert Belfour (2013), une scène pour 25 groupes suisses !!! et ce n'est pas fini (grace à vous)...


Pourquoi une levée de fond ?
Avoir de la trésorerie permet d'avoir de l'argent avant le jour J, et donc de :

Créer et imprimer des affiches, flyers, sous-bock, stickers et tous moyens de communication pour que ce soit une réussite !
Payer les billets d'avion des artistes américains qui viennent pour la première fois en Europe (et que chez nous).
2000- c'est 20% de nos besoin en mars, mais nous préférons les bonnes surprises ☺


Risques et défis
Nous savons qu'il est de plus en plus difficile de savoir de quoi demain sera fait, de prévoir un weekend aussi longtemps à l'avance, mais certains d'entre-vous ne manquerez pour rien au monde cette nouvelle édition, alors allez-y, bloquez votre agenda et profitez de ces petits prix.

 Avec plus de 900 visiteurs par jour (pour une capacité maximale de 1000), assurez-vous d'en être.
Soyez ainsi les sponsors d'artistes qui ne sont pas dans le circuit habituel.


D'autres façons d'aider :
Certains d'entres vous ne peuvent pas contribuer (pour l'instant) mais cela ne veut pas dire que vous ne pouvez pas aider :

Parlez-en autour de vous.
Partagez cette page Indiegogo

Partagez l'événement de facebook : https://www.facebook.com/events/1215968271794590/

Venez directement les 19 et 20 mai à Crissier.

Programmation 2017 :
Voici les 14 groupes qui animeront le festival :


Robert Kimbrough Sr. (USA) - Fils de Junior Kimbrough


The Hillbilly Moon Explosion (CH)

Reverend Peyton's Big Damn Band (USA)

Duck Duck Grey Duck (CH)

Cameron Kimbrough (USA) - petit-fils de Junior Kimbrough


Son of Dave (USA)
Ms Nickki & the Memphis Soul Connection (USA)
One Rusty Band n'Tap (CH)
Mark Muleman Massey (USA)
Ronan One Man Band (F)
Crushed Out (USA)
Sergi Estella (E)
The Blues Spirit Band (CH)
The Marshals (F)​+ DJ Phil (CH)


(programmation arrêtée au 12/01/2017, sous réserve d'annulation ou de modification)
And let's boogie all night long!Masterclass avec le Rev' Peyton :Apprenez le fingerpicking et le slide avec un des virtuoses du genre :

story:
Short Summary

With this campaign we are fundraising for children in the community of Thakarwadi in Maharashtra state, India. Money raised will enable us to buy solar lamps for the children to study during evenings as many homes have only a limited availability of electricity.

Nektarina Non Profit, a UK-based organisation dedicated to educating, connecting and inspiring people to care about their communities and their environment is coordinating this project with a local staff member based in Maharashtra who has visited the community and through whom we will organise the purchase of items in India.

Thakarwadi is a small village in the Pune district of Maharashtra, in central-western India. Financially, its inhabitants are very poor and they get food only if they work everyday and earn something. Consequently education is often not considered as a priority, as parents can’t afford the cost of education and keep the children at home to help them. Even though, children in the village have told us they believe education will help them to break the cycle of living day-by-day and many wish to become teachers or social workers and go on to help others.

Through our first crowdfunding campaign, students from the same community were provided with bicycles (as some of them had to walk around 6km a day to attend school) and with other school supplies.

In all we provided bicycles to 12 children from Thakarwadi village studying in Janseva Vidyakay Vadzire secondary school - 7 girls and 5 boys. They also received a collection of 8 books each. A special ceremony was organized at Janseva Vidyakay Vadzire secondary school to present the children with these items. Vice Chancellor of Nagpur University Dr. S. N. Pathan was chief guest at the function, and students, parents, people from local communities, Sarpanch (Village Head), and school committee members were also present.

The event was broadcasted on a local TV News Channel.

What We Need & What You Get

All money raised will go towards solar lamps no matter what our total is. If we raise below our target of £1000, we will simply buy fewer solar lamps. In the event that we exceed our target, we will buy additional solar lamps.

The Impact

35 children from the village currently attend schools. They don´t have electricity in their homes to study in the  evening/night so they use lamps that run on kerosene.

If we provide them with solar lamps they can study during the evenings. These lamps will also bring huge health benefits as students and others, particularly women, are currently inhaling large amounts of toxic smoke and fumes from these kerosene lamps. Replacing them with solar powered lamps will greatly cut down on these harmful gases. They also do not require fuel, thus saving money. These lamps are an appropriate and sustainable solution to this endemic problem.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by donating here on our page and by spreading the word!

story:
As we speak, we're constructing a Recycle and Community Center on the Chira Island in Costa Rica. This dream of the women association ADATA (Asociación de Damas Trabajando para el Ambiente) is a perfect and sustainable solution for the growing garbage problem on the island. But we really could use your help! 

We allready have a lot of actors supporting the construction of the center with material and financial donations. However, we still lack the funds to build the roof and that’s why we started this crowdfunding campaign: you can be part of this great project!



Why is this project important?

Presently there is no garbage collection whatsoever on the island; the 4000 inhabitants burn, bury or trash their (and the visiting tourists') solid waste somewhere on land or in the sea.

The risk of diseases like dengue, caused by wrongly disposed waste, will be reduced.

Many islands face similar waste problems; the Recycle and Community Center on Chira Island could be an example for them! 

The center offers not only a workplace but also a space for ADATA and other inhabitants to gather for meetings, events, trainings (e.g. environmental education for schoolchildren), exhibitions of handicrafts and a daycare center for the children of the women that are at work.

The design is of high aesthetic and functional quality; it combines traditional ways of living with modern building techniques, integrating the use of renewable energies like daylight, rainwater and recyclable material.


What do we need?

We're building a Recycle and Community Center that will benefit all the 4000 inhabitants of Chira Island, but we need your help to put a roof on the center! Your support will provide us with the lacking funds and help the women of ADATA  make their island clean again. 

What if we raise EVEN more? We will use that money to invest in a vehicle that the women of ADATA can use to collect the garbage on the island!


Impact of the project

First and foremost, the Recycle and Community Center is a structural and sustainable solution for the waste problems: an important part of the garbage on the island can be recollected in the center. The recycled materials (mainly glass, paper, cardboard, plastic and aluminium) will be transported to the mainland to sell to the big national recycling companies.

Secondly the project creates a source of income for the women of ADATA on an island where most people depend only on small-scale artisan fishing. Fishing is an unstable source of income and is also forbidden by the National Environment Ministry during 3 months a year in order to maintain an adequate level of marine resources. This project targets the economic empowerment of women in order to help them generate a steady income without having to leave the island.

Recycling is a viable business in Costa Rica, which will support increasing numbers of island women. This project will bring them and their business into the formal economy, out of economic precariousness and marginality.


Donations so far

Thanks to financial and material contributions the constructing of the center has already started.

A brief history

In 2009 a group of fisherwomen on the Chira Island created ADATA: Asociación de Damas Trabajando para el Ambiente (Association of Women Working for the Environment). They started to recollect recyclables because they were concerned about pollution and public health due large amounts of waste on the island. 

Initially, the women of ADATA operated from a abandoned house they had borrowed on the beach, from which they were evicted by the owner in 2012, leaving them without a workplace. They requested help to establish a suitable recycling facility to continue and expand the recycling program. In 2011 they presented a proposal to UNDP (United Nations Development Program) with support from UNA (Universidad Nacional). After approval, A-01 was contacted for the design and construction of the center. 


The building

A-01 started with a multidisciplinary design-and-build studio at the University Latina in Heredia (Costa Rica). 

The student designs, and the final design that came out of those designs, are formed by the principles of bioclimatic architecture. This means that the Recycle and Community Center is optimized for the use and performance in the local tropical climate through passive design elements such as roof overhangs and natural ventilation.                                                

Floor plan and elevations: the center is designed around two cores that enclose the main functions.


One core carries work-related components, the other one includes items needed for social activities. 


Bioclimatic section indicating flows of natural ventilation, rainwater and solar energy harvesting. 

Rendered image of the full design. Northwest view: the area on street level will be used for parking and loading or unloading of goods. 


Other ways you can help: get the word out!

Please help us to spread the message! Whether you donate to our campaign or not, you can still help make history. Share this campaign on social media, with your friends, family, and anyone you think that might be interested in this sustainable solution for the health and environmental problems on Isla Chira. It's only a few clicks for you and it makes a HUGE difference for the women of ADATA, their families and neighbors! 

Thanks!

story: This past 2014-2015 season for the Workman Arts and Entertainment Academy Band and Color Guard program was EXTREMELY successful. Our entire 2014 marching season was made possible by our private donors. You've helped us do it before, and we know we can count on you to help us do it again! This fall the WAEA stepped into SCSBOA field competition for the third time. In completions we earned 16 1st or 2nd place at each of our 8 competitions in 2A Division. In championships they earned 6th place out of 31 bands over all in our division. This was a big jump from Last years 12th place in 2A division. We need to continue to reach higher and get better. This year we would like to have another original score and drill designed and tailored for the Workman band to give us the competitive edge. As a result of our success in the 2014 season we are expected to grow in numbers which will increase costs for everything including drill design. We hope to raise enough to accomplish this project and have it ready for the 2015 fall season. All funds raised over our goal amount will still help support the WAEA's fall field program. This $4000 goal is only 1/10th of what it cost to keep the WAEA program afloat every year. We know we can count on our music, performance, and youth supporters. To see the look on a group of students faces when they see how all their hard work can pay off in becoming a champion is a look I personally would like to witness year after year.

story:
Short Summary

Vegetable Circus is a program of the Allied Wellness Education Network, a 501(c)3 non-profit. It is our mission to use circus arts to teach children creative and exciting ways to grow up healthy. Interactive assembly shows, structured multi-week enrichment programs, and hands-on workshops educate kids about living healthy in engaging and confidence-raising ways that support their development.  Since 2005, Vegetable Circus has expanded to offer services to schools and community organizations across America.  Our most active regions are in New England, North Carolina, and California. Between 2012 and 2014, Vegetable Circus performed over 100 assembly shows and provided over 1,000 hours of after school enrichment programming in Elementary schools across the country, delivering our wellness message to over 40,000 children! 

With a growing demand for Vegetable Circus services across America, it is necessary to maintain our national liability insurance policy. In years past we have been able to maintain our insurance policy with revenue from our services, but with the growing costs of expansion and as a non-profit, we cannot afford it without you! Please help us leave a lasting impression and a greater impact of our wellness message on children, families, and schools across america!


What We Need

Our funding goal is $1,500 and 100% of your donations will go straight to renewing our national liability insurance policy. This is vital to ongoing Vegetable Circus services at many elementary schools and also to the expansion of Vegetable Circus services into new communities. If we exceed our goal, additional money we raise will go to enhancing our assembly shows and enrichment programs. 


What You Get

In addition to the satisfaction you will have knowing that you contributed to enriching young student lives, you will receive a receipt from Firstgiving.com which authenticates your donation as tax deductible. You will also receive one of many unique perks with your donation. Our perks offer a large variety of items and services that also make spectacular gifts!  


    The Impact

    Vegetable Circus inspires children to make healthy decisions and take care of their growing bodies.  Vegetable Circus services teach children the three ingredients to healthy living which are healthy eating, healthy moving, and healthy relaxation.

    With a growing epidemic of child obesity, it is imperative to bring this message of wellness to schools and communities across the nation.  We have received feedback from children, parents, school faculty, and community event organizers that Vegetable Circus services get children excited about living and eating healthy. We frequently hear that Vegetable Circus programs stimulate children more than the average program and leaves a lasting impression on children. This fundraiser will help Vegetable Circus expand enriching services to schools and communities across America!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Every small donation counts! Even if 75 people donate just $20 each, we will have met our fundraising goal! We know that some fans may not be able to contribute at this time, and that is okay because you can still help! Make some noise about our campaign and share it with your friends, family, co-workers, school affiliates, and whomever else you think would help contribute. Share our Indiegogo page on social media sites and support our worthy cause! Thank you so much for all of your support and contributions! We greatly appreciate every effort!
