That's okay! It'd be great if you'd spread the word to family and friends who might have an interest in supporting this; and either way, thanks for reading!

story:
FREE AMINA !
Dear friends, Amina is asking for support ! 
She needs protection and safe shelter until september.
Join us at the campaign to support Amina ! Donate please !
http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/soutienaaminapremierefementunisienne?show_todos=true

 

LIBEREZ AMINA !
Chers amis, Amina vous demande de la soutenir !
Elle a besoin de protection et d'un abri sûr d'ici septembre.
Soutenez cette campagne ! Soutenez Amina ! Faites un don !
http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/soutienaaminapremierefementunisienne?show_todos=true

 

Campagne de soutien à Amina 

 

Le 17 mars 2013, Amina, la première Femen Tunisienne a été kidnappée et séquestrée par sa famille. Alors qu’elle était majeure.

Après une importante campagne de mobilisation internationale, la famille l'a laissée parler à des journalistes. Nous avons alors eu la confirmation, qu'elle était retenue contre son gré, battue par un cousin,  et qu'elle était dramatiquement soumise à un traitement chimique forcé.

Le 12 avril, Amina a réussi à s'enfuir.  Elle a pu récupérer ses papiers. Mais ils sont périmés, et elle est en train de refaire ses papiers. Elle est maintenant en sécurité grâce à tous.

Mais malgré l'élan de solidarité, ce qui a été déployé n'est qu'une solution d'urgence transitoire. Il faut maintenant qu'elle puisse envisager l'avenir. En toute sécurité et en toute sérénité.

Pour qu’elle continue à vivre de manière indépendante et qu'elle puisse décider de ses choix de vie, nous, ses soutiens, avons décidé de lancer cette campagne par crowdfunding. 

Des demandes de bourses d’études ont été faites, et seront en place à la rentrée. Et nous sommes sur des pistes pour un hébergement.

Dans l'immédiat, nous avons besoin de 4000 euros (5200 $).

L'argent récolté servira à payer ses déplacements et son hébergement d'ici septembre.

 Si nous réussissons à avoir plus, nous pourrons subvenir à ses besoins au delà de septembre. 

L'aspect pratique de l'appel à dons sera géré par Prochoix, qui tiendra à jour sur le site, les résultats de la campagne.

Dès la réception par Prochoix des dons, via la plateforme crowdfunding,  Nadia El Fani qui est en contact quotidien avec Amina sera l'interlocutrice chargée de cibler ses besoins et de les régler.

 

Merci

 

Collectif Free Amina   http://freeamina.blogspot.fr/

Fiammetta Venner (Prochoix)

Nadia El Fani, réalisatrice tunisienne

 

 

Free Amina support campaign

 

March 17th 2013, Amina, first Tunisian Femen was kidnapped and held  against her will by his family. While she was major.

After a major international mobilization campaign, the family had to let Amina speak to reporters. We then had confirmation that she was held against her will, beaten by a cousin, and she was dramatically subjected to a forced chemical treatment .

April 12, Amina managed to escape. She was able to get her papers. But they are outdated, and is redoing his papers. It is now safe thanks to all.

But despite the solidarity, what has been deployed is a temporary emergency solution. We now need her to look ahead. Safely and with confidence.

So that she continues to live independently and she can decide her life choices, we, her supporters, have decided to launch this campaign crowdfunding.

Applications for her scholarship have been made, and will be in place in September. And we are on track for an accommodation.

In the meantime, we need 4,000 euros ($ 5,200).

The money raised will be used to pay the travel and accommodation, food and security until September.

If we can have more, we can meet her security needs beyond September.

The practicality of the call for donations will be managed by Prochoix, which will maintain the site, the results of the campaign.

Upon receipt by Prochoix donations via this crowdfunding platform, Nadia El Fani is in daily contact with Amina will be responsible for targeting Amina needs and address them.

 

Merci

 

Collectif Free Amina   http://freeamina.blogspot.fr/

Fiammetta Venner (Prochoix)

Nadia El Fani, réalisatrice tunisienne

story:
Hello Friends!  As many of you know my sister Carmencita (Social Worker from Universidad del Valle) is living en El Valle (Bahia Solano -- Choco) and her work includes promoting art as a means of social transformation.  Recently, with local artists, formed the group Yubarta - Humpback Whales in Growth, and qualified for the upcoming Music Festival of the Pacific Petronio Alvarez that is held in my Cali, becoming the first group from Bahia Solano to participate in this important event.

On this occasion I come to you in the name of the Migration Festival, Carmencita wants to take artists from the Bogota music group Voodoo Souljah's to the town of El Valle, Bahia Solano.  The group does workshops with children from the village.  We need to purchase round trip airplane tickets Bogota - Bahia Solano for 2 artists (who are not even charging for these activities).  The idea is to raise the 1,300,000COP  ($705 USD) as soon as possible.

Any form of support is welcome, and we thank you for reading this far, your collaboration (ideas: round up money at home or at work…)

PS  If for the generosity of my friends we raise an amount higher that the cost of the tickets, we will purchase musical instruments to give to the kids of the village.  Obvsiously at the end of the activity I will publish the expenses y share with you guys the fotografic register respectively.  Any doubts, complaints or suggestions please tell me.

---The Migration Festival is an environmental festival that was born as an initiative of the National Park La Ensenada de Utria, but that the communities of Bahia Solano and Nuqui (Choco) have adopted as well, converting itself into a very important educational and recreational space (the only space on the Pacific Coast of Colombia that is dedicated to environmental education.)  The festival was organised because this thine of the year we are visited by the spices such as humpback whales, sea turtles of the carey, cana y caguama, beach birds, etc.  Many of these are endangered species.

story:
Greetings family, friends, and strangers! As the halfway point of my junior year at Loyola University in the great city of New Orleans approaches, I've been looking forward to something very exciting during this upcoming holiday season. Last semester, I was accepted into the Ignacio Volunteers program, and I'm jetting off to the small Caribbean country of Belize THIS CHRISTMAS.

I, along with nine other team members will be living in a small Mayan village with no running water or electricity for about a week, hosting a Christmas camp for the Belizian children there. We'll be teaching math, reading, and arts & crafts in the morning, and playing sports in the afternoon! The team is super excited for this amazing opportunity, but we need your help!

I am responsible for fundraising $1300 for the Ignacio Volunteers program, and as the date for our departure quickly approaches, I'm looking for a way to reach more people and reach my goal! If you are able, please donate what you can and help send me to Belize! Thanks so much!! :)

story:
Lifting Hope for Haiti's Orphans 

Ladies and Gentleman, thank you for viewing our page.  The video above shows the harsh truth of what it is like growing up poor in Haiti.  Something as simple as a red wagon that you and I may view as a toy, they viewed as a way to transport dead children to the crematorium.  These harsh realities lead us to believe that we must do something to offer opportunites that would be unimaginal otherwise.

This August four of us will be traveling to Haiti to establish a relationship and foundation for continuous humanitarian efforts with the end goal of building a charitable organization.  Haiti is only the starting point; we plan to extend our efforts to impoverished areas at home and abroad.  Our vision is to affect change by providing health, fitness, and education to youth, as well as the volunteers working in Haiti.    

Below is more information about the organizations your donations will be benefiting.  Below that, you can learn more about who we are, and our personal motivations.  

How will we LIFT HOPE?

What better way to lift hope and raise money than a Fundraising WOD (Workout of the Day)?  Whether you are competing, or donating to someone that is competing, you will make a difference!   

On August 17th, we will sweat and suffer together in order to raise money for this cause and give back to a community in need.  We will have two events: one for teams and one for individuals.  For more information on the event, please view the following link on Facebook: www.facebook.com/haitisorphans

Organizations Benefiting

Nuestros Pequeños Hermanos™ International:  A Christian mission that strives to provide a permanent family and home for orphaned, abandoned and other at-risk children who live in conditions of extreme poverty. Our programs provide quality education, health care and spiritual formation with the goal of raising good Christians and productive members of their respective societies.

St. Damien's Children's Hospital:  The healthcare programs of Nos Petits Freres et Soeurs are motivated by the gospel command to care for the sick and strive to offset the injustices of poverty and unemployment which make healthcare inaccessible for many poor people. Poverty imposes a tremendous burden of sickness and suffering on many children. In an effort to help precisely these children, St Damien Hospital offers both children of poverty, and children of any social level in emergent distress, quality and dignified healthcare. St. Damien always seeks to include the parent participation in this care through ongoing dialogue, on-site opportunities for education, and encouraging any level of material support they can offer for the care of their children.

Artists for Peace and Justice:  We are committed to long-term, sustainable development in direct partnership with the Haitian people. Our model is simple: we believe in empowering local communities, fostering economic growth, and the power of education to change a nation.

Angels of Light:  Under the NPH umbrella, the Father Wasson Angels of Light (FWAL) program founded the St. Anne Baby House and St. Louis Child Protection Camp. These homes have been a safe haven for the displaced and vulnerable children from Haiti’s devastating earthquake in 2010. Today, over 180 children underage 14 receive care, education and spiritual formation in the loving tradition of “St. Helene,” our flagship facility in Kenscoff, Haiti. Many of the grown children of St. Helene now serve as caregivers and teachers to this new generation of NPH children.

The organization Pwoteje Lavi Timoun yo (PLAT):  In Haiti, the children are growing up themselves in a harsh environment where the social, economic, and cultural conditions represent a shortfall for many of these children preventing them which are, inter alia: the right to housing, the right to health, the right to proper nutrition, the right to education.  Those most affected are: the orphans, the handicaps, the street children, the children in domestic situations, the abused children who are victims of ill treatments, the exploitation, violence and negligencing taking into account the mentality of the country or the medium in which they are in.

This alarming situation pushes them with the creation of the aforementioned organization to contribute their shares in order to mitigate these problems through their activities... Our goal is to help them with this as much as possible.

Who We Are

Brendan Ridings:  Brendan first traveled to Haiti in 2010. He was first hand witness to the conditions there. What cannot be imagined here is a living reality for children there. Brendan's aim is to empower the youth of Haiti so they have the tools to create the change they need. Brendan believes that by reaching across boarders and helping, this world economy can be affected and conditions here can be improved. Brendan has been involved with many charity organizations and fundraisers benefiting local, national, and international efforts. He is a nutritionist, NASM personal trainer, Corrective exercise specialist, CrossFit Level-1 trainer, and has done private practice counseling. This cause is also an effort to engage young people here to improve themselves, their community, and nation. Haiti is just the beginning. 

Eric Hargarten:  Eric joined the U.S. Air Force at age 17 and did six years active duty.  During that time some of his work included humanitarian and force protection work in Iraq and social work in Germany.  He was also a key physical training leader for the physical fitness development of Airmen.  He is a CrossFit Level-1 Trainer and ISSA Certified Fitness Trainer.  Eric has committed himself to a life of Service Before Self, and wishes to share his knowledge and compassion with the less fortunate.  He has seen firsthand the unfortunate disease and mis-education that is the result of living under an oppressive dictatorship.  He is a strong believer that in order to really affect positive change on a society, it starts with the education of young minds.  He just got out of the Air Force in May, and after much reading and education he knew that Haiti was his next project.  

Eric has previously done successful fundraising and volunteering for MS, prostate and testicular cancer, Big Brothers Big Sisters, Ronald McDonald House Charities, and the Special Olympics.

Eric Ridings:  Eric is involved with Chicago Cares charity. Eric works within the community he lives and also wants to reach abroad. He works as a NASM personal trainer, Corrective exercise specialst, CSCS, and physique competitor. Eric believes in inspiring the individual and bringing change through individual transformation. "One child at a time, and the entire world can change". He hopes to inspire the youth he works with in Chicago by working in one of the poorest nations on this planet.

He works as a NASM personal trainer, Corrective exercise specialst, CSCS, and physique competitor. Eric believes in inspiring the individual and bringing change through individual transformation. "One child at a time, and the entire world can change". He hopes to inspire the youth he works with in Chicago by working in one of the poorest nations on this planet.

story:
What is Yes To The Arts?

Before I tell you what we are, let me explain how we came to be. I've been working in education for the past 15 years and a classroom teacher for 3 of those years. Over the years, I've noticed a disturbing trend: the arts were slowly being phased out the schools I worked in. The reason for this? Mainly budget cuts and growing focus on standardized testing. As schools re-shaped their schedules to add more hours of academics, time for the arts was either shortened or eliminated. I thought, what can I do?


I stumbled upon a book called "Start Something that Matters." It was written by the guy who started TOMS shoes. Long story short, this book gave me the inspiration to start Yes To The Arts. What if I could start a business that could actually give the arts to schools? And, what could I sell to fund the program? It was very important to me to keep the program free, I strongly believe that the arts should always be a part of every child's public education. Our program follows a basic format. We bring in highly qualified dancers, actors, visual artists and musicians, and they teach mini-workshops in an after school setting.

So, I decided that a t-shirt would be the best and most appealing item to sell. Everyone wears them and it's the easiest way to spread our message. I didn't want to create a basic t-shirt, though. The t-shirt we created is a vintage-style light-weight cotton shirt; this way it fits into anyone's wardrobe. I want our customer to feel good when they buy it and when they wear it. Every shirt sold = one opportunity for a child to particpate in the program. 1 shirt, 1 opportunity. 

 

What We Need

We need at least $5,000 to start. Here's where it will go:

  • Marketing campaign: we need to get the word out. Your contribution will help us launch an aggressive campaign to attract schools who need our program and customers buy our shirts.
  • Supplies: In order to give our students a high quality program, we need supplies. Paints, recorders, sheet music, scripts etc. 
  • T-shirts: We want to expand our brand. Right now we have 4 designs, we need more. We are currently working with a designer to create more choices for you.

 

The Impact

There has never been a better time for a program like Yes to the Arts. Currently 20% of Arizona schools are without arts programming. And, that's just Arizona. Imagine what other states are dealing with. It's time to make positive change in our schools, and you can start by supporting a program like Yes to the Arts.  Here's how the arts have positive impact on students:

  • Arts instruction provides an incentive to attend school. And, once the students are there they are more likely to be successful in other areas.
  • Arts instruction teaches logic, problem solving skills and teamwork.
  • Arts instruction helps students understand the world around them.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? No problem. You can help us by sharing this campaign with everyone you know. The more the message is shared, the better.

story:
My Story

Hi!  My name is Kayla Johnson.  I'm a 13 year old, seventh grader, from Cordova (Memphis), TN.  I'm pretty normal, I guess.  I like to dance, listen to music, and hang out with friends at the mall. 

 

So, last summer, I got a letter from Duke University, inviting me to take the ACT ( a college entrance test).  My Mom and Dad were so excited, but all I could think of was, "oh boy something else to study for".  Well, I didn't study, but I did go to an ACT prep program that my Mom's sorority offered.  (My Mom is a Delta).  That program taught me how to take the test.  It must have worked because I did really well on the ACT. Actually, I rocked it!

 

Last week I got a few letters, inviting me to go to a summer program for "gifted students".  I'm a good student, but I never thought of myself as "gifted." Pretty cool stuff, huh?  It sounds like a great opportunity and I really want to go.

 

I hope you will help.  Even if you cannot give anything, please forward my information to other people who may be able to help.

 

My Mom always says, "It takes a village to raise a child."  Thanks for being a part of my village!

 

Kayla

The Impact

So, what happens if you give?  You will help me explore education from a different perspective.  I will be on a college campus, taking classes from a college professor, living in a dorm.  What more could a girl ask for?

What I Need & What You Get

I need money.  About $5000.  I know it sounds like a lot, it is! The money will pay for the summer program and travel expenses (hopefully I get to fly).  If I don't raise all of the money, I hope my parents will be able to make up the difference.  I don't want to ask them yet, that's why I'm asking you.  I don't have much to give in return except a big Thank You, but I'm sure I will think of something.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by donating, posting my information to your facebook pages, forwarding my information to others, email blasts and praying. Thanks again!

story:
Project Harmony Israel (PHI)

PHI aims to create a safe social space for Arab and Jewish children from Jerusalem to relate to one another as peers. In a system where divisions are pervasive, entrenched, and often self-imposed, change is hard to implement. PHI seeks to plant the seed of change: one that begins with children by giving them the chance to imagine their community as one rooted in shared experience, intellectual freedom, and social awareness. 

Why do I (Bridget) want to volunteer with PHI?

  • As a recent college graduate from Lesley University in Cambridge MA with a B.A. in History and minors in both education and psychology I was looking for a meaningful way to spend my summer between college and "real life". When I learned about PHI their mission immediately drew me in. PHI brings together my passions of travel, working with youth and adolescents as well as working towards conflict resolution and social change. 
     
  • PHI runs their summer camp program entirely through the use of volunteers. The mission of PHI is something that I truly admire and wish to be a part of. In order for me to be able to be a part of this opportunity I need to raise enough money to cover my cost of living while volunteering in Israel. 
     
  • I can use all the help I can get to make this opportunity a reality. Working towards peace in the Middle East is extremely complicated and complex. However, children are where change begins, and PHI's approach to teaching peace is unique and something I sincerely wish to participate in.  

In order for this fundraising campaign to be considered successful:

  • My goal is to raise $2,500. â€¨ 
  • I will use whatever money is raised to help me cover my travel and living expenses. â€¨ 

"A small body of determined spirits fired by an unquenchable faith in their mission can alter the course of history." -Gandhi

  • Contributions can be made in the form of a donation, through spreading the word about this fundraising campaign, or through both. â€¨ 
  • Any and all help is genuinely appreciated!

For more information about PHI, please visit their website:

  • http://www.projectharmonyisrael.com/index.html

For more information about me, my plans, etc. please contact me at:

  • brundqui@gmail.com

story:
In Oklahoma…

·       *Less than 51% of graduating high school seniors go on to attend college.

·       **Of those that do attend, only 44% will graduate.

·        The reason most students don’t attend college: They can’t afford it.

We’ve been fighting those odds for almost thirty years.  It’s time the world knew.

 

The Simon Estes Educational Foundation, Inc.: Who We Are

Led by Jayne L. Reed, a small group of Tulsans met with opera star Simon Estes who was in town to perform with the Tulsa Opera. Bound by a mutual belief in the importance of education and concern for the many bright high school seniors financially unable to attend college, the group decided to do what they could to assist these promising young students. As a result, in 1983 The Simon Estes Educational Foundation, Inc. was created with Mr. Estes and Ms. Reed as Cofounders.

To date, the Foundation has awarded an incredible 333 scholarships to academically gifted, highly motivated students whose dreams of higher education would have been in jeopardy without our scholarship program.  This program has existed through the generosity of individuals like you who understand that an education is the single most powerful weapon against ignorance, poverty, and crime—it can bridge social, economic, racial, and geographic divides like no other force on Earth. 

Many of our students are first-generation college students who greatly desire to change the course of their lives by way of higher education.  Most have overcome extreme challenges and  major hardships in their personal lives.  All of them are extraordinary individuals who have worked hard, fought against the odds, and proven themselves Scholars in the truest sense of the word.

The Project: Simon Saves

For many years, we at The Simon Estes Educational Foundation, Inc. have been told by our supporters that the stories of our Simon Estes Scholars confirm the positive impact that our program has had on their lives. We heard them! Unfortunately, the staggering cost of creating such a collection of touching narratives has been prohibitive.

Until now.

Thanks to an extraordinary offer of a reduced fee, we are in the process of producing a first-rate documentary chronicling the sometimes harrowing, sometimes heartbreaking, always inspiring stories of our beloved scholars. However, we have yet to raise the funds needed for promotion and circulation.

That’s where we need YOU!

With your help, we can share these poignant tales of hope with the world.

 

* http://www.okhighered.org/oeis/preparation/CollegeRate.shtml

** http://www.higheredinfo.org/dbrowser/?level=nat...

story:
Connections That Matter

Bob is a 52 year old man who owned his own successful business the day before his stroke. The day after his stroke, he felt like he was living in a different country, where he could only recognize a few words and wasn't sure how to say what he needed. Aphasia is the loss of language due to a stroke or other brain injury.

Living with aphasia is hard. You start to lose your friends because you can't communicate with them, and even family members are sometimes at a loss for what to do or say. You feel all alone.

That's why the Speaking Out! program of the National Aphasia Association is so important. It is a conference that connects people with aphasia and their families to others who are living in similar circumstances, and to the information and resources they need to get back to living successfully and happily.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking you to donate as much as you can so we can offer Speaking Out! in Orlando, Florida, on May 23-24, 2014. Sources of funding from past years are no longer available, so we are counting on contributions from facilities, clinics, corporations, therapists, and people with aphasia and their families so that we can offer this program. (For sponsorship and advertising opportunities for your clinic, private practice, or hospital program, please contact Cheryl Paul, capaul@usf.edu).

The donations you make will pay for: speakers, program book, conference materials, lunch and snack breaks.

Of the 1 MILLION people living with aphasia in the U.S., almost 100,000 of them live in the state of Florida (estimated based on prevalence rates). But most of them only have access to the support of others and information that makes their life better at an event like Speaking Out!

The Difference It Makes

The Speaking Out! program has existed as part of the National Aphasia Association for 15 years. Over the years, it has provided support to thousands of individuals living with aphasia around the United States.

Programs like these have long-lasting effects. Six months after attending a conference like this, participants are participating in more activities in their home community, have a better understanding of their aphasia, and have better family relationships.

Just a one- or two-day program makes a big difference.

If you want to help, but can't give money...

Share the link to this site with as many of your neighbors and friends as you can. Maybe they can help.

Ask other organizations or churches where you're a member if they will donate in your honor.

Ask everyone around the lunch table at work, or in your aphasia group, to contribute $1.

story:
UMOJA CENTRE - Tanzania, creating brighter future for the Youth

Our Vision:

To help young Tanzanian people to get educated, empowered and living free from poverty, abuse and exploitation

YOU CAN HELP TOO.

Umoja receives 50% of its funding from generous sponsors from around the world who sponsor individual students to complete their education.  In July, we have a full time Sponsorship coordinator joining our team, but until this time...

WE NEED YOUR HELP.

Your help will enable us to continue to support our 44 outplacement students by paying school fees and purchasing the required text books and uniforms needed by our students to assist them secure a brighter future.

All of the students at Umoja appreciate the opportunity they are being given and are aware that this will change, not only their futures, but the futures of their families.

Your donation, no matter how big or small, will help to break the cycle of poverty these students will face without assistance.

What is UMOJA?

Started in 2009, UMOJA is a youth development organisation in Arusha, Tanzania (East Africa). We administer a free educational and support programme, specifically designed for vulnerable young people (aged 14-24) who are lacking in opportunities and living in poverty. The programme consists of a Foundation Year designed to give them the best chance of future success,  during  which they learn English, I.T., Maths, Life Skills, etc. They are also given resources which help them to care for their physical and emotional wellbeing. Once they have successfully completed the Foundation Year, students become part of the Outplacement Scheme whereby they are placed into the mainstream education system or vocational training. Umoja then supports its students through job applications into new careers which will allow them to provide effectively for themselves and their families.

For more information, please visit our website (umoja.com.au) or contact us : info@umoja.com.au

WEBSITE : UMOJA.COM.AU
FACEBOOK  PAGE : facebook.com/TheUmojaCentre

story:
Short Summary

Millions of ancient manuscripts from Timbuktu and the Great Empires of West Africa radically changed the image and legacy of Africans and African Americans in world history.

Dismissed for centuries as simple and illiterate by the West, a flood of recently resurfaced documents in Africa clearly prove the existence of highly literate and complex societies that valued education more than their vast reserves of gold.

The most significant benefit of the exhibit is the documented knowledge that African Americans will learn, particularly the youth, of the literacy of their ancestors and the positive contributions that Africans made to the world community. 

Return proof of great accomplishments of direct relatives from the past to engage kids and adults with the confidence and sense of self to do great things in the future. We all benefit.

The exhibit at the Fort Worth Museum of Science & History starting in 2014 will feature rare African manuscripts that prove the dominance of literacy and learning characterizing Timbuktu for over 700 years. The exhibition will be supplemented with educational and outreach programs that deliver this critically important message outside of the museum walls.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds raised will be divided into the following areas:

  • Supplement exhibit construction funds
  • Produce Timbuktu education programs (Child and Adult curricula)
  • Market & promote Timbuktu exhibit, education & cultural programs

* Funding supporters can receive official Legacy of Timbuktu merchandise.

The Impact

This exhibition will restore a great, important world legacy to a large community affecting all Americans today. This legacy was replaced with a destructive narrative that demads social justice, so we can all move forward as a nation and world leader.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out on this critically important, historic exhibition.

  • Blog, Email and Share the Legacy of Timbuktu exhibition story.
  • 'Like' & 'Share' us on Facebook (www.Facebook.com/TimbuktuTexas).
  • 'Follow' us on Twitter (www.Twitter.com/TimbuktuTexas).

People should know about this great history and the great humanity that exists in us all, every one. Thank you for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Hi! For those of you who don't know me, my name is Daniela. I am a 22-year-old living in Yuma (AZ) who has decided (with a lot of God's nudging's, and kicks and pushes, haha) to launch in an indefinite journey as a missionary. 
If you do not know what a missionary does, here's a brief explanation: anything and everything. 
To be honest, for now, all I know is that the following six months will include some strong teachings, but a whole lot of something else. You see, I will become the hands and feet for things many others require payments for doing, and do it for free. Whether it is building houses, or teaching, or just having a conversation over a cup of coffee with someone who's hurting. I will go to the places where I'm called to do whatever is needed. 
Missionary work is different for everyone, and for me, the case stands. 
For me, missionary work is a piece of cake, that is, if it revolves around people who are in immediate need (like Hatians, living in tiny cottages in the DR). I find it easy to sit on the floor in a house with no windows, and play with half-naked children even if they look like they haven't showered for days. Don't get me wrong, there are still plenty challenges to that type of missionary work, but for me, it is the one in which I am most comfortable. 
That is why, when I felt called to go to England of all places, I sort of panicked. This means I don't just get to knock on someone's door or give a dollar to a kid I'll never again see in my life. It means I create a relationship and keep it going. It means I come into a person's life and not leave it, and act on what I preach, not just say it. 
Thus, I am highly excited about this opportunity to attend DTS in London. I will be in a place far away from home where I will be left with nothing but to learn and start acting, instead of just sitting in my bubble of comfort. I am actually going out into the world and using what I learn to hopefully change people's lives for the better, and to be honest, it's about time. It's about time I become one less person who talks and talks but doesn't do. I am really excited about going out there and doing, even if I don't know what it is until I'm there. I am ready, and I hope you are ready to come with me, because whether it is only in spirit, through your support, you will be there with me every step of the way. 

What I Need & What You Get

All funding received will be put towards paying for the school phase as well as an outreach phase all through YWAM. Anything else will be saved for any future trip opportunities. 
Funding for this is, in a way, a one way street. You will not get any money or such in return. It is my hope, though, that my visit there will be enough to make the difference in at least one person's life, and if that is the case, that difference will have been made not only by me, but by you through your funding. Because without you, I might have not been there. 

The Impact

Personally, this will be a great opportunity for me to grow. I will be learning how to communicate and work with people better, as well as create a form of discipline in my life. 
Not only that, but I get to interact with new people and establish a (hopefully) lasting relationship, regardless of their religious affiliation. 
I hope to create an impact and learn how to use my gifts and talents to help those around me. 

With this training, I can launch in an indefinite journey of travel to places in need of my help. A couple of places I would like to visit after this training include India, Syria, Ukraine, and Haiti. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share to others whom you know can contribute. Anything helps!

Pray! There can never be enough prayer, ever.

story:
Hi everyone!  Thanks for taking the time to check out our campaign.

This summer Statement Arts is teaming up with the legendary Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center to provide a free summer music and theater program for 50 underserved New York City kids!

The Need:

Many public school students in New York Cities' underserved communities have little or no access to the Arts. There is a real need to empower underserved, minority and low-income youth through arts education that goes beyond the classroom. Often times when budgets are tight, music and arts programs are the very first things to get cut and sadly, there are many kids in New York City with no music or arts classes at all!

We Can Help...

At Statement Arts, a 501(c)(3) located in New York City, we recognize the importance of a well-rounded liberal arts education and we hope that our new Summer Program, Empower Youth Through Performance, will introduce kids to musical theater, igniting their creative fire. Partnering with the Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Cultural Center, Empower Youth Through Performance will work with 40–50 students, grades 3-6 and 7-9, over the course of two weeks.

We also plan to launch a college prep program for 10 kids!

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a summer program for 50 kids in NYC is a challenge! All funding obtained for this project will go towards the renting the space, a piano/keyboard, lights, chairs for the final performance for our audience, food for the reception, paying the teaching artists, insurance and if we raise the whole amount, tickets for the kids to see a show on Broadway!

Any additional money raised, will got towards other Statement Arts programs. Whatever you are able to give- $10, $50, or $200, we promise it will make an impact.

Statement Arts would like to offer every student an equal chance to participate at no cost to them.                                                                         

 As a 501(c)(3), all money donated to Statement Arts is tax-deductible!

The Impact

Students who have participated in our programs have had many successes, such as a Bill & Melinda Gates Millennium Scholarship recipient, Honor Roll and National Honors Society members, a Sundance Film Festival participant, and most have gone onto higher learning institutions. 

Funding for this and upcoming projects will enable Statement Arts to open a larger umbrella securing more young artists’ education projects, underwriting the cost of mentoring activities, and ensuring a plan that will sustain new projects in 2012 and years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign with your friends can really make a difference. Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  Like us on facebook, tweet about us, forward our campaign on to all of your friends.

We'd like to thank everyone who helps us with this program and we look forward to empowering many more kids in the future.

About Us

Statement Arts is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization whose mission is to build self confidence and enrich underserved youth with creative experiences through arts education: Music, acting, dance, photography, visual art, filmmaking and writing. We believe that these arts education channels enhance young people's intellectual performance and self esteem, enabling them to become ambassadors in their communities.

For the past ten years, our core focus has been the Urban Arts Project, which filled the immediate needs of the art and music programs at the High School of Environmental Studies (HSES), an underserved public school in New York City’s Hell’s Kitchen.

www.statementarts.org


A HUGE Thank you to Ari Espay for his amazing photos! Check out more of his work at   www.fancygirlstreetboy.com

story:
Mission Statement

The Illuminated Cities Project seeks to give young people, especially those in communities affected by segregation in both urban and suburban spaces, an opportunity for leadership, self-development, and community-development in an international context.  Fellows in the program build life skills, develop an Action Plan for their home-community, and are partnered with a mentor and a local organization to help them implement their Action Plan on the ground level. The fellows will be change agents for their home-communities, creating a cycle of revitalization and development. 

Short Summary

For the pilot project, we are aiming to take five fellows and five mentors from the segregation affected areas of metro-Detroit and Chicago to Mexico City. Currently, the fellows are engaged in The Illuminated City-Stories Project, which is an opportunity for reflection and documentation of their realities. Fellows are also in the process of creating action plans for their home communities. Fellows will receive pre-departure trainings and mandatory readings/videos and will study the work of a social entrepreneur in Mexico. During their time in Mexico, they will have an opportunity to meet social entrepreneurs in the Mexican context, lead workshops about the work they are doing in their home contexts, and further develop their action plans with their assigned mentors. Mentors and fellows will work together upon return to the local home context to implement action plans and continue The Illuminated City-Stories Project.

What We Need

The cost of sending a fellow abroad is approximately $1500.  We're aiming to send 10 fellows abroad on our first piolot program in Mexico and are seeking to raise $15,000 by the end of November.


The Impact

Youth will return with a better understanding of need in global communities, including how that need is addressed, and use their experience to implement an Action Plan of growth and development in their hometown.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even a dollar will go a long way. However, we are also in need of creative artists and mentors to work with our youth and individuals to help us spread the word.

story: Hi, My name is Felicia. The pic you see above is my son Quincy. Quin is attending Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD) for photography.  I am his mom and I am funding his education alone with the help of financial aid and loans which still do not cover all the costs. SCAD is $52,000 per year and has posed a financial hardship on me but I believe in my son and feel that he should have the opportunity to follow his dream. I managed to get him through two of the three quarters by using my 401k and any other money I had. We lowered his course load to be able to pay his tuition but this last quarter I was unable to pay the last $5000.00 that he owed. I am asking for an additional $1000.00 just to send with him to obtain a place to live, food and books for the upcoming year. As it stands now Quin cannot return to school until I clear this debt. I am working to provide a place for us to live and pay the household bills. Quin has a part-time job and he is saving to get a place to live because we cannot afford the on campus housing. This campaign is my last hope to send him back to school. It is my hope that you will read this and be moved to help us. Quincy will not be going to school anywhere if we cannot come up with the funds to at least satisfy the debt he owes. I cannot express the hope that I am putting into this plea for assistance. I don't have any other resource to turn to. I think if 6000 people read this and everyone gives just a dollar we will make our goal. I'm hoping that 6000 people and $1.00 can change my son's life. He doesn't know that I am doing this but if I could tell him that 6000 people cared enough about his future to give, I think that would change him profoundly.  Anything we raise will go to clearing his school debt. If you cannot give, please pass the word about this campaign. You will be giving to us still. Thank you for reading this and thank you for giving.

story:
About the project

Hello my dear friends, my name is Nikos Inglezakis and I'm a photographer and graphic designer from Crete in Greece. I am trying to help as much as possible the people in need, so I decided to publish a photo album of my work. If I manage to collect the money required for publishing, I will donate 50% of the sales of each book to an organisation that provides food to more than 1000 people every day. I have the network to sell the books, I just don't have the funds to print it.

The organisation that will receive the money is http://kytaroxalepas.blogspot.com/

Sorry in advance for the non-Greek speaking people - Try to use google translate because it is all in Greek  :)

Product and goal

The photo album will be a very professional and expensive work with a hard cover. It will have 200 pages with unpublished black and white photographs of mine - dimensions 25x35 cm. I will possibly add some colour pictures also! It will be a very interesting coffee table book with mostly portraits and nude art pictures.

You can all view some of my work at: http://statigr.am/ingleland 

You can see an interview I gave some months ago for an American blog for men at: http://www.thedignifieddevil.com/woman-art#more-4300

I will publish 1000 copies to start with and sell them for 100,00€ each. That means that I will give 50.000,00€ to the organisation mentioned above.

I wish to thank everybody in advance for helping me help others.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help by donating please feel free to make some noise about this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools or any other ways you can imagine.

Thank you all so much!

story:
Empowerment Through Aquaponics-

The WI- Kerala Connection 

Growing Networks is an international collaborative that seeks to bring the wealth of  aquaponic farming - system of growing fish and plants in a re-circulating water system- to communities world-wide- starting in Kerala, India.  By creating glocal networks in which, information, ideas, and resources around aquaponics can be exchanged, Growing Networks will aid in the re-imagination of the world food system to encourage local production and consumption of highly nutritious food that promotes the values of the triple bottom line, and emphasizes the need for multi-diciplnary education that integrates environmental stewardship, nutrition, and food production.

 

The Growing Networks pilot project “Empowerment through Aquaponics- The Wisconsin- Kerala Aquaponics Connection” will progress in the summer of 2012, through collaboration between Sweet Water Foundation, Mahattil, LLC, the University of WI- Madison, and St. Albert’s College of Kochi, India.  

 

The program will introduce a group of UW-Madison student interns to the sustainable development of aquaponics in India, through a service-learning project.  The students will

  1. Build the first aquaponics system at an aquaculture institute in Kochi, India.  
  2. Transform the wet lab at the University featured below into an aquaponics learning center.  



  1. Build a scalable system, that is adapted to local markets and can be used to educate the community on the promise of aquaponic farming.

 

  1. Engage in Interdiciplinary learning via the Sweet Water AQUAPONS curriculum (diagramed below) 

We need your support!  We have recieved an award from UW-Madison to make this project possible, but need more funding to make this project sustainable and scalable.  Our project is

Locally Rooted

    • We are working with students, and a local university to construct a system that is adaptable to the culture and environment of Kerala

Environmentally concious

    • Aquaponics has the unique ability to produce large amounts of highly nutritious fish and produce while addressing problems such as drought, overfishing, and environmental stress caused by traditional agricultural methods

Education Based

    • Aquaponics is an ideal tool by which to teach the STEM (Science Technology, Engineering, and Math) diciplines.  

Your donation will help us teach local communities about a practical technology that they can take command of and adapt to thier environment and culture.  

 

Why Aquaponics? 

  • holds promise in creating sustainable food systems that yield large amounts of quality produce, and fish (which can begin to address overfishing), 
  • does not produce significant amounts of waste product that not only harms the environment but the health of populations.  
  • is adaptable and can be made in any size and shape aquaponics makes it plausible to grow food locally-from small areas in classrooms and houses to large factory cultivation.  

We deeply believe that the introduction of Aquaponic farming will transform communities in that itis minimally water intensive compared to traditional agriculture, thus addressing major issues of drought and erratic monsoon, while allowing communities to be innovative with the system, growing both cash crops, and nutritious produce to feed their families. Additionally, Aquaponics can be used within the classroom as an educational tool to teach students about Science, Engineering, Math, and Technology and Art. Our partner, Sweet Water Foundation, is now creating a full curriculum platform that we will be using to bring aquaponics to schools in India as well called AQUAPONS funded by the MacArthur foundation and HASTAC.  

 

Why Growing Networks?

Growing Networks is a collaborative.  We operate on the core belief that in order to create sustaianble change we have to engage various groups, organizations, communities, and people in the movement.  Growing Networks seeks to connect people who are interested in the fledgling aquaponics industry to those who have already established themselves as key players.  Our key collaborators include:

Sweet Water Foundation

Sweet Water Organics

Mahattil LLC

St. Alberts College

UW-Madison

Kottapuram Integrated Development Society (KIDS)


Our Team aditionally has experience working in India to promote aquaponics.  James Godsil, president of Sweet Water Foundation, and co-founder of Sweet Water Organics, was sponsored by the State Department to speak on Aquaponics in India.  Chaya Nayak, the co-organizer of Growing Networks, spent a year in India studying the feasibility of Aquaponics in 2010.  

 

We are constantly bringing in new contributors both at the local and global level and seek to create networks of networks because it is with these networks that we can truly provide resources to communities so that they can adapt aquaponics.  By contributing to our project you will become a part of the NETWORK.  

 

In the News! 

Aquaponics and the Sweet Water Foundation/ Sweet Water Organics model have been heralded by the UN World Cities Program, IBM, and the Economist, as an emerging method of food production that has the potential to impact not only food security, but also education, jobs, and the general health of communities. Sweet Water Foundation has additionally recieved grants from the USDA and HASTAC's digital media learning competition.  

 

For more information on the value of aquaponics or on prior aquaponics projects in India, please visit our website and blog.

 

We Need YOUR help:

This campaign will help us raise funds to help us the first aquaponics test system in Kochi, India.  

We hope to surpass our goal of $8000 and reach our goal of $12000 to allow for aquaponics experts to accompany the students to Cochin, and oversee the project, as well as additional funds to allow for maintenance of and research around the system the students create, and the purchase of a locally produced solar panel to offset the barrier of electricity to power the system.  


Your contribution will help us begin to develop a model to train communities to take command of the technology and promote a local movement to create a healthy food system, while also impacting their educational system.  By supporting us in our first endeavor, you will be forming the base of the initiative, and allow us to conduct thorough research that will be used to create a sustainable social enterprise that can be replicated not only in other Indian cities, but in other countries as well.  

 

We hope that you will support us by making a contribution to our program and become part of the Growing Networks Community.  If your are unable to directly support our initiative, you can promote our program to your networks!  Click here to share our project on Facebook or Twitter, or perhaps mention us in a blog or conversation with friends!  

 

Remember, in order to make this movement sucessfull, we need to harness the power of NETWORKS!

If you have any questions or need further information, please feel free to contact us at GrowingNetworksIndia@gmail.com  or go to our website at GrowingNetworks.weebly.com.

Build a scalable system, that is adapted to local markets and can be used to educate the community on the promise of aquaponic farming.


 

Engage in Interdiciplinary learning via the Sweet Water AQUAPONS curriculum (diagramed below) 

We need your support!  We have recieved an award from UW-Madison to make this project possible, but need more funding to make this project sustainable and scalable.  Our project is
Locally Rooted



We are working with students, and a local university to construct a system that is adaptable to the culture and environment of Kerala


Environmentally concious



Aquaponics has the unique ability to produce large amounts of highly nutritious fish and produce while addressing problems such as drought, overfishing, and environmental stress caused by traditional agricultural methods


Education Based



Aquaponics is an ideal tool by which to teach the STEM (Science Technology, Engineering, and Math) diciplines.  


Your donation will help us teach local communities about a practical technology that they can take command of and adapt to thier environment and culture.  
 
Why Aquaponics? 

holds promise in creating sustainable food systems that yield large amounts of quality produce, and fish (which can begin to address overfishing), 
does not produce significant amounts of waste product that not only harms the environment but the health of populations.  
is adaptable and can be made in any size and shape aquaponics makes it plausible to grow food locally-from small areas in classrooms and houses to large factory cultivation.  
We deeply believe that the introduction of Aquaponic farming will transform communities in that itis minimally water intensive compared to traditional agriculture, thus addressing major issues of drought and erratic monsoon, while allowing communities to be innovative with the system, growing both cash crops, and nutritious produce to feed their families. Additionally, Aquaponics can be used within the classroom as an educational tool to teach students about Science, Engineering, Math, and Technology and Art. Our partner, Sweet Water Foundation, is now creating a full curriculum platform that we will be using to bring aquaponics to schools in India as well called AQUAPONS funded by the MacArthur foundation and HASTAC.  
 
Why Growing Networks?
Growing Networks is a collaborative.  We operate on the core belief that in order to create sustaianble change we have to engage various groups, organizations, communities, and people in the movement.  Growing Networks seeks to connect people who are interested in the fledgling aquaponics industry to those who have already established themselves as key players.  Our key collaborators include:
Sweet Water Foundation
Sweet Water Organics
Mahattil LLC
St. Alberts College
UW-Madison
Kottapuram Integrated Development Society (KIDS)

Our Team aditionally has experience working in India to promote aquaponics.  James Godsil, president of Sweet Water Foundation, and co-founder of Sweet Water Organics, was sponsored by the State Department to speak on Aquaponics in India.  Chaya Nayak, the co-organizer of Growing Networks, spent a year in India studying the feasibility of Aquaponics in 2010.  

 
We are constantly bringing in new contributors both at the local and global level and seek to create networks of networks because it is with these networks that we can truly provide resources to communities so that they can adapt aquaponics.  By contributing to our project you will become a part of the NETWORK.  
 
In the News! 
Aquaponics and the Sweet Water Foundation/ Sweet Water Organics model have been heralded by the UN World Cities Program, IBM, and the Economist, as an emerging method of food production that has the potential to impact not only food security, but also education, jobs, and the general health of communities. Sweet Water Foundation has additionally recieved grants from the USDA and HASTAC's digital media learning competition.  
 
For more information on the value of aquaponics or on prior aquaponics projects in India, please visit our website and blog.
 
We Need YOUR help:
This campaign will help us raise funds to help us the first aquaponics test system in Kochi, India.  
We hope to surpass our goal of $8000 and reach our goal of $12000 to allow for aquaponics experts to accompany the students to Cochin, and oversee the project, as well as additional funds to allow for maintenance of and research around the system the students create, and the purchase of a locally produced solar panel to offset the barrier of electricity to power the system.   

Your contribution will help us begin to develop a model to train communities to take command of the technology and promote a local movement to create a healthy food system, while also impacting their educational system.  By supporting us in our first endeavor, you will be forming the base of the initiative, and allow us to conduct thorough research that will be used to create a sustainable social enterprise that can be replicated not only in other Indian cities, but in other countries as well.  
 
We hope that you will support us by making a contribution to our program and become part of the Growing Networks Community.  If your are unable to directly support our initiative, you can promote our program to your networks!  Click here to share our project on Facebook or Twitter, or perhaps mention us in a blog or conversation with friends!  
 
Remember, in order to make this movement sucessfull, we need to harness the power of NETWORKS! 
If you have any questions or need further information, please feel free to contact us at GrowingNetworksIndia@gmail.com  or go to our website at GrowingNetworks.weebly.com.

story:
Inner-City Kids Funding

Currently, the students that I have in my Inner-City Program in East Harlem, in which I teach 4 days a week of two groups of ten students, will have their Blue Belt Promotion Test this coming March. However, the student’s parents whom are low-income I will not ask to cover their kid’s Promotion Test, because I do not wish to burden them with an expense that they cannot afford. Moreover, I cannot afford to cover the belts myself since my Org. is only 2 years old; i.e., newly formed.  Nevertheless, one day in the future, I will be able to finance my deshis (disciples) Karate is all aspects, that is my aspiration, but for now, I or more aptly stated, THEY need assistance.


Subsequently, I humbly request funding for my deshis’ test. This benevolence is greatly appreciated by me and will be on behalf of my deshis and it will cover the cost of the belts (obis) with embroidery (the names of the students) on them.


So far, this program is going well (again) and it has been received very well by the aforesaid students as well as the school. Not to mention, I have the largest group(s) of kids too! Additionally, I am hoping that over this summer that the school implements summer programming.

Benevolence

Again, I beseech your help and I hope that you can be so kind as to assist them in their Karatedō experience, so I can give them a true test and reward them with their deserved ranks, because I teach them at a low hourly rate, which is fine and agreed to do. Furthermore, I assure you that they will be thrilled as they are already excited about potentially testing as they inquired about already, and in which,  I expressed that I am trying to get the funding to manifest this: their test.


Thankfully, this is my Organization’s 4th school program and second Inner-City one, but the first one covered the fees for the discounted Promotion Test fees as I had 30 middle and high school students!

Thank You!

Arigato gozaimasu (thank you very much) for your time and PLEASE consider helping and also sharing the LINK on your FB or Google+ home-pages, so that others may wish to help as well.


                                                                                             ~ OSU! Rivera Sensei

FaceBook Link: http://www.facebook.com/senseiriveraosu

Genjōkōan Karate Organization FaceBook Link:
https://www.facebook.com/RiveraSensei?sk=app_191246264290645

Genjōkōan Karate Organization Blog Link: http://genjokoankarateblog.blogspot.com/

Sensei Rivera Google+Profile: https://plus.google.com/117589757140283918283/posts

Rivera Sensei E-Mail: riverasensei@genjokoankarate.org

story:
Hi,

I am an Addiction Specialist, Marriage and Family Therapist, and Art Therapist. I have worked in non-profits serving pre-teens, teens, and transitional age youth (youth age 18-24), for over 10 years. Here in the East Bay of California, which includes Oakland and Richmond, many of our youth are being left to deal with violence, racism, poverty, and abuse, on their own. I hope to fill that gap. Contributors can help me get my vision off the ground to the point where it will be self supporting.

Your founding will help my pay for the first few months of office space in a location accessible by public transportation. It will pay for art supplies, journals, and games. I have found that most youth respond best to creative based therapies. And it will pay for basic office supplies such as lockable file cabinets, a lockable brief case and other basic essentials. Any funds will help. If I don't make my goal it will still get me farther along the way. I am committed to this goal. If I don't get funds it will mean I cannot immediatley provide the breadth of services I would like to provide.

Children in this area, as well as the surrounding areas are regularly exposed to violence, drugs, abuse, racism, and sexual exploitation. If they don't come across a non profit agency they are left to deal with these issues on their own. In my work with non-profits the youth I work with consistently tell me how much I helped them, and bring other youth to me to help as well. Please help me help them.

if you can't contribute please help by spreading the word. And check out the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
UPDATE

Huntridge lovers, wondering what's the latest with the Theatre?  What did the crowdfunding money go to?  And what about that million bucks from the City, is that still there?

Well, we all know nothing good comes easy, and if anything this project is confirmation of just how GREAT the Huntridge is!  It's been quite a rollercoaster, but rest assured Huntridge Revival and a dedicated team of supporters are still working hard to put the puzzle pieces together and bring our beloved Huntridge back to life. 

The good news is we've found a new investment group that's very capable, wants to move quickly, and has aligned interests in the historical significance and future use.  We are working through the financials and due diligence with them and hope to have some good news soon!

The crowdfunding money raised was used for ongoing deposits on the property, legal work, administration costs, and for basic exterior improvements (paint and lighting) to help alleviate the blight.  Thanks again to everyone who contributed, as this seed capital was the thing that made this project possible!

The $1 million grant from the City of Las Vegas via the Centennial Commission is still earmarked for the project.  Special thanks to the efforts of Councilman Bob Coffin who has been spearheading it.  Additional thanks are due to the rest of the City Council, and the Centennial Commission including Councilman Ricki Barlow, Historical Preservationist Bob Stodal, Mayor Carolyn Goodman, and the other members who have all been very supportive of the cause.  We also want to thank the Huntridge Foundation for all of their ongoing efforts to document and preserve the historical significance of the Huntridge.  This is truly a community-wide project and it takes the support of so many to keep it alive.

Stay tuned for more updates, and good news, coming soon!

-Huntridge Revival

____________________________________________


The Huntridge Theater may be the most beloved historic landmark in Las Vegas. But over the last decade, the community that loves it has watched it helplessly fall into a seeming final state of disrepair.  

El Teatro Huntridge es el sitio histórico más querido de Las Vegas. Pero en la última década, la comunidad que lo aprecia lo ha visto caer en un total estado de abandono. Queremos traerlo a su gloria  de nuevo y que se convierta una vez más en el sitio preferido en Las Vegas para las artes y programas comunitarios.

We want to end this madness, and bring The Huntridge back for the people that love it. 

We plan to bring this Theatre back to all its glory and more, and make it once again Las Vegas' favorite venue for performing arts and community programming.

The downtown entrepreneurs who undertook to kick off this effort recognize that many attempts to do this have failed despite concerted efforts and massive, long-term community support, and this might be the last shot to save it (covenants on the property expire in 2017). But the tools for organizing community engagement and support have evolved so much, so quickly -- we can do this.

Even if we raise this campaign’s full amount and end up with $150,000 or more, that’s obviously not even close to enough to lovingly renovate, and reopen, or even buy the Huntridge.

But! It will prove that community support exists to justify much larger private investment in a project that is motivated more by passion than just profits.

It will give us a great shot at getting the $4M in the door to secure the property that the current owners are asking for before the end of the year. Once the Mizrachis no longer own it, the process of working with the community to renovate it together can begin, without particular time pressure. 

Renovating the Huntridge could cost up to $10 million more (based on initial engineers' walkthrough of the guttend building), so if we can show interested investors how much the community still cares about the Huntridge by raising the first ~1% of the to cost from its fans, and in doing so pass smaller initial financial hurdles that are beyond our personal means, we are confident that this show of community support will preface a beautiful revival of the greatest music and arts venue Vegas has ever known.

Nostalgic Huntridge-lovers of all stripes, this is where you come in: Help us prove that community support is there, by funding the important pre-work of this iconic revival project!!!

Queremos acabar con esta locura y devolver el Huntridge a la gente que lo aprecia. 

Los miembros de la Comunidad de Negocios del Centro de Las Vegas que están detrás de esta iniciativa, reconocen que muchos intentos para lograrlo han fracasado a pesar de esfuerzos conjuntos y un enorme apoyo de la comunidad, y esta es quizás la última oportunidad de salvarlo (el contrato de la propiedad se vence en el 2017). La capacidad para organizar el apoyo de la comunidad ha evolucionado rápidamente y sabemos que podemos lograrlo!

Si aumentamos el monto de la campaña a $150.000 o más, no es ni siquiera suficiente para comprar, renovar y abrir de nuevo el Huntridge.

Pero! Comprobará que el apoyo de la comunidad existe, y así justificar una gran inversión privada en este proyecto que está motivado más por pasión que por ganancias.
Comprar y renovar el Huntridge puede costar unos $15 millones de dólares, y si podemos demostrar a los inversionistas que están interesados, lo mucho que la comunidad quiere salvar al Huntridge al recolectar el 1% del dinero por los miembros de la comunidad, y de esta manera cubrir la inversión inicial que está por encima de lo que nosotros podemos cubrir.
Tenemos la plena confianza que esta muestra de apoyo de la comunidad será el comienzo de la bella recuperación del mejor escenario para la música y las artes que Vegas ha tenido hasta ahora.

Para todos los nostálgicos amantes del Huntridge esto es donde necesitamos de su ayuda:
Ayúdenos a comprobar que el apoyo de la comunidad existe, contribuyendo a la recuperación de este gran icono.

 

What do we need the money for?

We extended all our personal financial resources to come up with the first $60k for the non-refundable deposit and appraisals to make this process possible. The next chunk of deposit ($50k) is due immediately after this campaign ends, and we have an estimated $100k of required costs before we can start bringing in (already very interested) private investors for the project. These costs include remediation due diligence, environmental certifications, appraisals, legal work, renovation design work and marketing materials, etc, all by the end of the summer. These start-up costs would normally be much more for a project of this magnitude, but we expect that we'll be able to get it all done very efficiently thanks to many tentative offers we've received to volunteer professional services.  Estimated costs are as follows:

$20k - Due Diligence / Feasibility Studies  

$15k - Marketing / Web Development / Admin

$50k - Architectural / Design / Engineering

$15k - Inspections / Appraisals / admin

$50k - Second Deposit

$150k Total Start-up Capital Required

Para que necesitamos el dinero?

Nuestro grupo ha reunido todos nuestros recursos disponibles y contamos con los primeros $60.000 para el depósito y estudio de valorización no reembolsable para poder iniciar este proyecto.
Los próximos $50.000 deben pagarse inmediatamente al finalizar esta campaña, y hay costos estimados de $100.000 antes de poder presentar el proyecto a inversionistas privados que ya están muy interesados. Estos costos incluyen: certificados de ambiente, valorización, documentos legales, diseño del proyecto de renovación y materiales de mercadeo, todo esto debe hacerse al finalizar el verano.
Estos costos iniciales suelen ser mucho más altos para un proyecto de esta magnitud, pero esperamos hacerlo de la manera más eficiente gracias a las ofertas tentativas que hemos recibido de profesionales que donaran ciertos servicios.
Estos son los costos estimados:

$20.000 – Auditoría externa / Estudios de factibilidad

$15.000 – Mercadeo / Desarrollo página web / Administración

$50.000 – Arquitectura / Diseño / Ingeniería

$15.000 – Inspecciones / Valorización / Administración

$50.000 – Segundo depósito

$150.000 Total del capital Inicial requerido

Who are you? 

This IndieGoGo campaign was initiated by The Huntridge Revival, LLC, which was founded by Downtown Las Vegas community members Joey Vanas, Michael Cornthwaite, and Rehan Choudhry, and adopted by members of #startupblock, a group of entrepreneurs and community organizers living near The Huntridge.

Quienes somos?
La campaña IndieGoGo fue iniciada por The Huntridge Revival, LLC, fundado por los miembros de Downtown Las Vegas Community, Joey Vanas, Michael Cornthwaite, y Rehan Choudhry y adoptados por los miembros de startupblock, un grupo de emprendedores de tecnología que viven cerca del Huntridge.

Are contributions tax-deductible?

No, Huntridge Revival is an LLC because this campaign is only a necessary first step towards raising up to $15MM in total investment and it needs to also attract private investors and be able to show returns.  Because it is not a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization contributions are not tax-deductible.  To avoid ever rehashing its current fate if we do nothing, the Huntridge does need to sustain itself financially once reopened (while keeping ticket and food and beverage costs affordable). 

More details about the campaign and the Huntridge can be found at Save.TheHuntridge.com!

Las donaciones son deducibles de los impuestos?

No, Huntridge Revival es una Sociedad de Responsabilidad Limitada ya que esta campaña es solo un primer paso necesario para alcanzar la meta de $15 millones en inversión total y atraer inversionistas privados y mostrar rendimiento de su inversión.
Debido a que no es una organización sin fines de lucro 501(c)3, las donaciones no son deducibles de los impuestos.
Para evitar que ocurra de nuevo su destino actual si no hacemos nada para rescatarlo, el Huntridge necesita mantenerse a si mismo financieramente una vez abierto para que los costos de boletos y comida y bebida sean razonables.

Para más detalles sobre la campañna y el Huntridge consulte la página web: Save.TheHuntridge.com

$15.000 – Inspecciones / Valorización / Administración
$50.000 – Segundo depósito
$150.000 Total del capital Inicial requerido
Who are you? 
This IndieGoGo campaign was initiated by The Huntridge Revival, LLC, which was founded by Downtown Las Vegas community members Joey Vanas, Michael Cornthwaite, and Rehan Choudhry, and adopted by members of #startupblock, a group of entrepreneurs and community organizers living near The Huntridge.
Quienes somos?La campaña IndieGoGo fue iniciada por The Huntridge Revival, LLC, fundado por los miembros de Downtown Las Vegas Community, Joey Vanas, Michael Cornthwaite, y Rehan Choudhry y adoptados por los miembros de startupblock, un grupo de emprendedores de tecnología que viven cerca del Huntridge.
Are contributions tax-deductible?
No, Huntridge Revival is an LLC because this campaign is only a necessary first step towards raising up to $15MM in total investment and it needs to also attract private investors and be able to show returns.  Because it is not a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization contributions are not tax-deductible.  To avoid ever rehashing its current fate if we do nothing, the Huntridge does need to sustain itself financially once reopened (while keeping ticket and food and beverage costs affordable). 
More details about the campaign and the Huntridge can be found at Save.TheHuntridge.com!
Las donaciones son deducibles de los impuestos?
No, Huntridge Revival es una Sociedad de Responsabilidad Limitada ya que esta campaña es solo un primer paso necesario para alcanzar la meta de $15 millones en inversión total y atraer inversionistas privados y mostrar rendimiento de su inversión.Debido a que no es una organización sin fines de lucro 501(c)3, las donaciones no son deducibles de los impuestos.Para evitar que ocurra de nuevo su destino actual si no hacemos nada para rescatarlo, el Huntridge necesita mantenerse a si mismo financieramente una vez abierto para que los costos de boletos y comida y bebida sean razonables.
Para más detalles sobre la campañna y el Huntridge consulte la página web: Save.TheHuntridge.com

story:
Short Summary

   Hello! My name is Krystal Thomas and I was just accepted into a Dual Degree Masters program for George Mason University and the University of Malta. In this accelerated Masters Program, I receive two Masters degrees in one year: a Masters of Science from George Mason University in Conflict Analysis and Resolution and a Masters of the Arts from the University of Malta in Conflict Resolution and Mediterranean Security. Not only will I be participating in such a competitive program, but will be completing my degrees overseas in the beautiful country of Malta.

   After earning my Bachelors degrees in Psychology and Conflict Analysis and Resolution, I discovered my strong passion for conducting research on conflicts based on identity, culture, beauty, self worth, and values. My goal as a researcher is to help people be able to better understand themselves and others around them who may be similar or different. I want to talk about the social issues that affect marginalized groups in our population in the hopes of giving them a voice. This will create a better environment to actually move towards constructive resolution.

   The moment I heard about this program, I knew it was the right one for me. Not only will I learn more about analyzing and resolving conflicts around the world, but also I will be submerged in a brand new environment. After spending last summer overseas in Indonesia in a graduate level study abroad program titled: “Indonesia: Culture and Conflict,” I truly appreciate the opportunity of learning in a new location. My experience in Indonesia allowed me to not only become a better researcher and conflict analyst, but enabled me to grow as a person. This allowed me to realize the type of work I wanted to spend the rest of my life doing. I am so excited to be given the opportunity to further my education in Malta.

What We Need & What You Get

    I have already been accepted into the University of Malta Dual Degree Program with George Mason University. Due to the fact this is an accelerated Masters program, I am not allowed to work during the program. I have applied for loans to cover my tuition for the year so now the only expense that I have left is to pay for an apartment and living expenses such as groceries and public transportation.

   For one year an apartment around 500 euros ($662.20) will be roughly $8,000.00 without water and electricity. Water and electricity would be roughly another 100 euros per month ($1,590.00).

    Because of the short time frame, I decided to set the goal for $4,000.00, but all donations are welcomed. This will not entirely cover all my expenses, but it will be extremely helpful for paying several months rent. I truly appreciate all of the support no matter the costs. I have been so blessed so far in my life and I am excited to see what is next. 

The Impact

   I have already made progress in this area. As an undergraduate student, I created two original research studies. I have done the most with my research study titled Black Women Making and Breaking the Mold: The Influence of Stereotypes on Identity. From this study alone, I was able to not only present my findings in several conferences; I created a group on campus. The goal of this group was to create a sense of sisterhood amongst the women who participated in my research study in the hopes of empowering them to confront many of the issues within the Black community. After each group session, I would blog about our discussions in hopes of inspiring others to take action in confronting negative societal stereotypes about Black women.

   Since the creation of the blog and inspirational video, we have had the opportunity to reach so many women around the world. This has created such an impact because we have made a safe space for Black women to talk about issues and form a sense of sisterhood with other women with similar experiences to them. My work has only just started. I am hoping to continue writing about my research and experience within the group. While in Malta, I will continue doing similar research by analyzing the ongoing conflict of mass immigration of North Africans into Malta. I want to look into how this is impacting Maltese society and how immigrants from North African are adopting to life in Malta. 

Other Ways You Can Help

   Honestly, thank you so much for taking the time to read my campaign. I understand if you are unable to make a financial contribution now, but you can still help! I ask that you talk to family and friends about my campaign and what I hope to do – make a tremendous impact in the Conflict Analysis field by focusing on issues on culture and identity. Together, we can really make a difference by bringing to light conflicts in the hopes of moving towards resolution.
